direction.raw_text: grinding against track, slowing. FOLDING TABLE LEGS scissoring open. The LEVER of a train door being pulled. NAMES on lists on clipboards held by clerks moving alongside the tracks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...Rossen... Lieberman... Wachsberg...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: coming down off the passenger train.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: being set out on the folding tables. HANDS straightening pens and pencils and ink pads and stamps.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...When your name is called go over there... take this over to that table...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: rapping a name onto a list. A FACE. KEYS typing another name. Another FACE.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...youre in the wrong line, wait over there... you, come over here...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is taken from one long line and led to the back of another. A HAND hammers a rubber stamp at a form. Tight on a FACE. KEYS type another NAME. Another FACE. Another NAME.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As a hand comes down stamping a GRAY STRIPE across a registration card, there is absolute silence... then MUSIC, the Hungarian love song, "Gloomy Sunday," distant... and the stripe bleeds into COLOR, into BRIGHT YELLOW INK.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...Biberman... Steinberg... Chilowitz...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The song plays from a radio on a rust-stained sink. The light in the room is dismal, the furniture cheap. The curtains are faded, the wallpaper peeling... but the clothes laid out across the single bed are beautiful. The hands of a man button the shirt, belt the slacks. He slips into the double-breasted jacket, knots the silk tie, folds a handkerchief and tucks it into the jacket pocket, all with great deliberation. A bureau. Some currency, cigarettes, liquor, passport. And an elaborate gold-on-black enamel Hakenkreuz (or swastika) which the gentleman pins to the lapel of his elegant dinner jacket. He steps back to consider his reflection in the mirror. He likes what he sees: Oskar Schindler -- salesman from Zwittau -- looking almost reputable in his one nice suit. Even in this awful room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A spotlight slicing across a crowded smoke-choked club to a small stage where a cabaret performer sings. Its September, 1939. General Sigmund List's armored divisions, driving north from the Sudetenland, have taken Cracow, and now, in this club, drinking, socializing, conducting business, is a strange clientele: SS officers and Polish cops, gangsters and girls and entrepreneurs, thrown together by the circumstance of war. Oskar Schindler, drinking alone, slowly scans the room, the faces, stripping away all thats unimportant to him, settling only on details that are: the rank of this man, the higher rank of that one, money being slipped into a hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in front of the SS officer who took the money. A lieutenant, hes at a table with his girlfriend and a lower-ranking officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The waiter is gesturing to a table across the room where Schindler, seemingly unaware of the SS men, drinks with the best-looking woman in the place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His sergeant doesnt. His girlfriend doesn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sergeant makes his way over to Schindler's table. There's a handshake and introductions before -- and the lieutenant, watching, can't believe it -- his guy accepts the chair Schindler's dragging over. The lieutenant waits, but his man doesn't come back; he's forgotten already he went there for a reason. Finally, and it irritates the SS man, he has to get up and go over there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His girlfriend watches him cross toward Schindler's table. Before he even arrives, Schindler is up and berating him for leaving his date way over there across the room, waving at the girl to come join them, motioning to waiter to slide some tables together.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: From the gentleman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do I know him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Find out who he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stay here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: and another round of drinks. The lieutenant makes a halfhearted move for his wallet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler's already got his money out. Even as he's paying, his eyes are working the room, settling on a table where a girl is declining the advances of two more high-ranking SS men.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: WAITERS ARRIVE WITH PLATES OF CAVIAR

dialogue.raw_text: Let me get this one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, put it away, put it away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as a waiter lays it down on another table that's been added to the others. Schindler seats the SS officers on either side of his own "date" -- SCHINDLER What are you drinking, gin? He motions to a waiter to refill the men's drinks, and, returning to the head of the table(s), sweeps the room again with his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: erupts from Schindler's party in the corner. Nobody's having a better time than those people over there. His guests have swelled to ten or twelve -- SS men, Polish cops, girls -- and he moves among them like the great entertainer he is, making sure everybody's got enough to eat and drink. Here, closer, at this table across the room, an SS officer gestures to one of the SS men who an hour ago couldn't get the girl to sit at his table. The guy comes over.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (like everyone knows) That's Oskar Schindler. He's an old friend of... I don't know, somebody's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: screws in a flashbulb. She lifts the unwieldy thing to her face and focuses. As the bulb flashes, the noise of the club suddenly drops out, and the moment is caught in BLACK and WHITE: Oskar Schindler, surrounded by his many new friends, smiling urbanely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A photograph of a face on a work card, BLACK and WHITE. A typed name, black and white. A hand affixes a sticker to the card and it saturates with COLOR, DEEP BLUE. People in long lines, waiting. Others near idling trucks, waiting. Others against sides of buildings, waiting. Clerks with clipboards move through the crowds, calling out names.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Groder... Gemeinerowa... Libeskind...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The party pin in his lapel catches the light in the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Behind Schindler, the door to another apartment closes softly. A radio, somewhere, is suddenly silenced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the door of this apartment, a man with the face and manner of a Talmudic scholar, finally nods in resignation, like his number has just come up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler offers a hand. Confused, Stern tentatively reaches for it, and finds his own grasped firmly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stern?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you Itzhak Stern?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Settled into an overstuffed chair in a simple apartment, Schindler pours a shot of cognac from a flask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern stares at the cognac Schindler's offering him. He doesn't know who this man is, or what he wants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler looks puzzled, then shrugs, dismissing it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He keeps holding out the drink. Stern declines it with a slow shake of his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler nods, takes out a cigarette case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He offers Stern a cigarette. Stern declines again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler lowers his voice as if there could possibly be someone else listening in somewhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He waits for a reaction, and misinterprets Stern's silence for a lack of understanding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Stern does understand. He understands too well. Schindler grins good-naturedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler tries for a moment to imagine what they could possibly be. He can't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern smiles despite himself. The man's manner is so simple, so in contrast to his own and the complexities of being a Jew in occupied Cracow in 1939. He really doesn't know. Stern decides to end the conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He laughs loudly, uproariously. But then, just as abruptly as the laugh erupted, he's dead serious, all kidding aside -- SCHINDLER You know anybody? Stern stares at him curiously, sitting there taking another sip of his cognac, placid as a large dog.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shrugs; it sounds more than fair to him. But not to Stern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern studies him. This man is nothing more than a salesman with a salesman's pitch; just dressed better than most.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There's a company you did the books for on Lipowa Street, made what, pots and pans?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause) By law, I have to tell you, sir, I'm a Jew.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, you've done it -- good company, you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It did all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know anything about enamelware, do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was just the accountant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Simple engineering, though, wouldn't you think? Change the machines around, whatever you do, you could make other things, couldn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Field kits, mess kits...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Army contracts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Once the war ends, forget it, but for now it's great, you could make a fortune. Don't you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with an edge) I think most people right now have other priorities.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get the contracts and I'm sure you'll do very well. In fact the worse things get the better you'll do. It was a "pleasure."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The contracts? That's the easy part. Finding the money to buy the company, that's hard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jews, yeah. Investors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause) Jews can no longer own businesses, sir, that's why this one's for sale.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, they wouldn't own it, I'd own it. I'd pay them back in product. They can trade it on the black market, do whatever they want, everybody's happy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pots and pans.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding) Something they can hold in their hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know anybody who'd be interested in that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a slow knowing nod) They should be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A mason trowels mortar onto a brick. As he taps it into a place and scrapes off the excess cement, the image DRAINS OF COLOR. Under lights, a crew of brick-layers is erecting a ten-foot wall where a street once ran unimpeded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A young man emerges from an alley pocketing his Jewish armband. He crosses a street past German soldiers and trucks and climbs the steps of St. Mary's cathedral.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARY'S CATHEDRAL - DAY A dark and cavernous place. A priest performing Mass to scattered parishioners. Lots of empty pews. The young Polish Jew from the street, Poldek Pfefferberg, kneels, crosses himself, and slides in next to another young man, Goldberg, going over notes scribbled on a little pad inside a missal. Pfefferberg shows him a container of shoe polish he takes from his pocket. Whispered, bored -- GOLDBERG What's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goldberg doesn't bother; he pockets his little notepad and intones a response to the priest's prayer, all but ignoring Pfefferberg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goldberg glances to Pfefferberg for the first time, and, greatly put upon, takes out his little notepad again and makes a notation in it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He flips the pad closed, pockets it, crosses himself as he gets up, and leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You don't recognize it? Maybe that's because it's not what I asked for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You asked for shoe polish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My buyers sold it to a guy who sold it to the Army. But by the time it got there -- because of the cold -- it broke, the whole truckload.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause) So I'm responsible for the weather?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I asked for metal, you gave me glass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is not my problem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is not your problem? Everybody wants to know who I got it from, and I'm going to tell them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Metal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Pfefferberg at the front desk of a sleepy hotel with another black market middleman, the desk clerk. Both are wearing their armbands. Pfefferberg underlines figures on a little notepad of his own -- PFEFFERBERG Let's say this is what you give me. These are fees I have to pay some guys. This is my commission. This is what I bring you back in Occupation currency. The clerk, satisfied with the figures, is about to hand over to Pfefferberg some outlawed Polish notes from an envelope when Schindler comes in from the street. The clerk puts the money away, gets Schindler his room key, waits for him to leave so he can finish his business with Pfefferberg... but Schindler doesn't leave; he just keeps looking over at Pfefferberg's shirt, at the cuffs, the collar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pfefferberg nods, Yeah, thanks, and waits for Schindler to leave; but he doesn't. Nor does he appear to hear the short burst of muffled gunfire that erupts from somewhere up the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pfefferberg knows he should say 'no,' let that be the end of it. It's not wise doing business with a German who could have you arrested for no reason whatsoever. But there's something guileless about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The clerk tries to discourage Pfefferberg from pursuing this transaction with just a look. Pfefferberg ignores it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The clerk tries to tell Pfefferberg again with a look that this isn't smart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler takes out his money and begins peeling off bills, waiting for Pfefferberg to nod when it's enough. He's being overcharged, and he knows it, but Pfefferberg keeps pushing it, more. The look Schindler gives him lets him know that he's trying to hustle a hustler, but that, in this instance at least, he'll let it go. He hands over the money and Pfefferberg hands over his notepad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he writes down the information, Pfefferberg glances to the desk clerk and offers a shrug. As he writes -- SCHINDLER I'm going to need some other things. As things come up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's a nice shirt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't know where I could find a shirt like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding) There's nothing in the stores.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have any idea what a shirt like this costs?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice things cost money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How many?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, ten or twelve. That's a good color. Dark blues, grays.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Write down your measurements.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Oberfuhrer Scherner and his daughter, in a wedding gown, dance to the music of a quartet on a bandstand, the reception guests drink and eat at tables set up on an expansive lawn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Other SS and Army officers share the table with Czurda. Schindler, too, nice blue shirt, jacket, only he doesn't seem to be paying attention; rather his attention and affections are directed to the blonde next to him, Ingrid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shrugs, There you have it. Brilliant. He glances off, sees something odd across the yard. Two horses, saddled-up, being led into the garden by a stable boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler gets up from the table. Scherner, his wife and daughter and son-in-law stare at the horses; they're beautiful. Schindler appears, takes the reins from the stable boy, hands one set to the bride and the other to the groom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scherner hails a photographer. As the guy comes over with his camera, so does just about everybody else. Scherner insists Schindler pose with the astonished bride and groom. Big smiles. Flash.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The SS doesn't own the trains, somebody's got to pay. Whether it's a passenger car or a livestock car, it doesn't matter -- which, by the way, you have to see. You have to set aside an afternoon, go down to the station and see this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you got thousands of fares that have to be paid. Since it's the SS that's reserved the trains, logically they should pay. But this is a lot of money. (pause) The Jews. They're the ones riding the trains, they should pay. So you got Jews paying their own fares to ride on cattle cars to God knows where. They pay the SS full fare, the SS turns around, pays the railroad a reduced excursion fare, and pockets the difference.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Ingrid) Excuse me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's nothing more sacred than marriage. No happier an occasion than one's wedding day. I wish you all the best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A neighborhood place. Bread, pastries, couple of tables. At one sits owner and a well-dressed man in his seventies, Max Redlicht.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Max looks at the man not without sympathy. He's never heard of such a thing. It's really a bad deal. But then -- MAX REDLICHT Let me understand. The Nazis have taken your money. So because they've done this to you, you expect me to go unpaid. That's what you're saying. The owner of the place just stares at Redlicht.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man doesn't answer. He watches Max get up and cross to the front door where he says something to two of his guys and leaves. The guys come in and start carting out anything of any value: cash register, a chair, a loaf of bread...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I go to the bank, I go in, they tell me my account's been placed in Trust. In Trust? What are they talking about, whose Trust? The Germans'. I look around. Now I see that everybody's arguing, they can't get to their money either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take you there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That makes sense to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Max strolls along the sidewalk, browsing in store windows. People inside and out nod hello, but they despise him, they fear him. Just as he's passing a synagogue, some men in long overcoats cross the street. Einsatzgruppen, they are an elite and wild bunch, one of six Special Chivalrous Duty squads assigned to Cracow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SAME TIME - DAY The Sabbath prayers of a congregation of Orthodox Jews are interrupted by a commotion at the rear of the ancient temple. Several non-Orthodox Jews from the street, including Max Redlicht, are being herded inside by the Einsatz Boys. They're made to stand before the Ark in two lines: Orthodox and non. One of the Einsatzgruppen squad removes the parchment Torah scroll while another calmly addresses the assembly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one does anything for a moment. The liberals from the street seem to say with their eyes, Come on, we're all too sophisticated for this; the others, with the beards and sidelocks, silently check with their rabbi. One by one then they file past and spit on the scroll. The last two, the rabbi and Max Redlicht hesitate. They exchange a glance. The rabbi finally does it; the gangster doesn't. After a long tense silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Einsatz NCO glances from Max to the rabbi and smiles to himself. This is unexpected, this rift.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Max admits it with a shrug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence. The Einsatz NCO glances away to the others, amused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody answers. He turns to Max.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls out a revolver and shoots the old gangster in the head. He's dead before he hits the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and walks away. The other Einsatz Boys pull rifles and revolvers from their coats and open fire.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I want you to spit on it. I want you to walk past, spit on it, and stand over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't been to temple must be fifty years. (to the rabbi) Nor have I been invited.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the rabbi) You don't approve of the way I make my living? I'm a bad man, I do bad things?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've done some things... but I won't do this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does this mean? Of all of you, there's only one who has the guts to say no? One? And he doesn't even believe? (no one, of course answer him) I come in here, I ask you to do something no one should ever ask. And you do it? (pause) What won't you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You, sir, I respect.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The rest of you... ...are beneath his contempt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In BLACK AND WHITE and absolute silence, a suitcase thrown from a second story window arcs slowly through the air. As it hits the pavement, spilling open -- SOUND ON -- and, returning to COLOR -- Thousands of families pushing barrows through the streets of Kazimierz, dragging mattresses over the bridge at Podgorze, carrying kettles and fur coats and children on a mass forced exodus into the ghetto. Crowds of Poles line the sidewalks like spectators on a parade route. Some wave. Some take it more soberly, as if sensing they may be next.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye, Jews.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The little folding tables have been dragged out and set up again, and at them sit the clerks. Goldberg, of all people, has somehow managed to elevate himself to a station of some authority. Armed with something more frightening than a gun -- a clipboard -- he abets the Gestapo in their task of deciding who passes through the ghetto gate and who detours to the train station.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pfefferberg, with his wife Mila, at the head of a line that seems to stretch back forever, flicks at Goldberg's OD armband with disgust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They consider each other for a long moment before Pfefferberg leads his wife past Goldberg and into the ghetto.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ghetto Police. I'm a policeman now, can you believe it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dismayed by each others' close proximity, Orthodox and liberal Jews wait to use the floor's single bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From the next apartment comes the liturgical solo of a cantor. In this apartment, looking like they can't bear much more of it, sit some non-Orthodox businessmen, Stern and Schindler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lets them think about it, pours a shot of cognac from his flask, offers it to Stern, who brought this group together and now sits at Schindler's side. The accountant declines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler lights a cigarette and waits for their answer. It doesn't come. Just a silence. Which irritates him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He caps his flask, pockets it, reaches for his top coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The investors study him. This is not a manageable German. Whether he's honest or not is impossible to say. Their glances to Stern don't help them; he doesn't know either. The silence in the room is filled by the muffled singing next door. One of the men eventually nods, He's in. Then another. And another.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: For each thousand you invest, you take from the loading dock five hundred kilos of product a month -- to begin in July and to continue for one year -- after which time, we're even. (he shrugs) That's it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not good enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not good enough? Look where you're living. Look where you've been put. "Not good enough." (he almost laughs at the squalor) A couple of months ago, you'd be right. Not anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Money's still money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it isn't, that's why we're here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did I call this meeting? You told Mr. Stern you wanted to speak to me. I'm here. Now you want to negotiate? The offer's withdrawn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do we know you'll do what you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because I said I would. What do you want, a contract? To be filed where? (he slips into his coat) I said what I'll do, that's our contract.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A red power button is pushed, starting the motor of a huge metal press. The machine whirs, louder, louder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SAME TIME - DAY Schindler, at a wall of a windows, is peering down at the lone technician making adjustments to the machine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler turns from the wall of glass to face his new accountant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern hesitates, then nods. The look on Schindler's face says, Well, what's to debate, the answer's clear to any fool.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The standard SS rate for Jewish skilled labor is seven Marks a day, five for unskilled and women. This is what you pay the Economic Office, the laborers themselves receive nothing. Poles you pay wages. Generally, they get a little more. Are you listening?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was that about the SS, the rate, the... ?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Jewish worker's salary, you pay it directly to the SS, not to the worker. He gets nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But it's less. It's less than what I would pay a Pole. That's the point I'm trying to make. Poles cost more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why should I hire Poles?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Another machine starting up, growling louder, louder -- EXT. PEACE SQUARE, THE GHETTO - DAY To a yellow identity card with a sepia photograph a German clerk attaches a blue sticker, the holy Blauschein, proof that the carrier is an essential worker. At other folding tables other clerks pass summary judgment on hundreds of ghetto dwellers standing in long lines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man tries to hand over documentation supporting the claim along with his Kennkarte to a German clerk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Over there, other "non-essential people" are climbing onto trucks bound for unknown destinations. The teacher reluctantly relinquishes his place in line.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a teacher.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not essential work, stand over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY The teacher at the head of the line again, but this time with Stern at his side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands over a piece of paper. The clerk takes a look, is satisfied with it, brushes glue on the back of a Blauschein and sticks it to the man's work card.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The world's gone mad.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a metal polisher.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Another machine starting up, a lathe. A technician points things out to the teacher and some others recruited by Stern. The motor grinds louder, louder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler wanders around a large empty apartment. There's lots of light, glass bricks, modern lines, windows looking out on a park.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The same place full of furniture and people. Lots of SS in uniform. Wine. Girls. Schindler, drinking with Oberfuhrer Scherner, keeps glancing across the room to a particularly good-looking Polish girl with another guy in uniform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scherner thinks he understands what Schindler's saying. Just in case he doesn't -- SCHINDLER I should send it to you, though, don't you think? You can forward it on? I'd be grateful. Scherner nods. Yes, they understand each other.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'd never ask you for money, you know that. I don't even like talking about it -- money, favors -- I find it very awkward, it makes me very uncomfortable -- SCHINDLER No, look. It's the others. They're the ones causing these delays.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What others?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whoever. They're the ones. They'd appreciate some kind of gesture from me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That'd be fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Done. Let's not talk about it anymore, let's have a good time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Scherner at his desk initialing several Armaments contracts. The letters D.E.F. appear on all of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Men and pulleys hoist a big "F" up the side of the building. Down below, Schindler watches as the letter is set into place -- D.E.F.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The good-looking Polish girl from the party, Klonowska, is shown to her desk by Stern. It's right outside Schindler's office. This girl has never typed in her life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Flames ignite with a whoosh in one of the huge furnaces. The needle on a gauge slowly climbs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A garage door slides open revealing a gleaming black Mercedes. Schindler steps past Pfefferberg and, moving around the car, carefully touches its smooth lines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another machine starts up. Another. Another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern with a woman at the head of a line. The clerk affixes the all-important blue sticker to her work card.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FACTORY DAY - DAY Three hundred Jewish laborers, men and women, work at the long tables, at the presses, the latches, the furnaces, turning out field kitchenware and mess kits. Few glance up from their work at Schindler, the big gold party pin stuck into his lapel, as he moves through the place, his place, his factory, in full operation. He climbs the stairs to the offices where several secretaries process Armaments orders. He gestures to Stern, at a desk covered with ledgers, to join him in his office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The accountant follows Schindler into the office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler goes to the wall of windows, his favorite place in the world, and looks down at all the activity below. He pours two drinks from a decanter and, turning back, holds one out to Stern. Stern, of course, declines. Schinder groans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He comes over and puts the drink in Stern's hand, moves behind his desk and sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He dismisses them with a shrug; he's never had much use for either. But the third -- he raises his glass to the accountant. Stern's glass stays in his lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern slowly raises his glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler drinks; Stern doesn't.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sit down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My father was fond of saying you need three things in life. A good doctor, a forgiving priest and a clever accountant. The first two...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (long sufferingly) Just pretend for Christ's sake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Klonowska, wearing a man's silk robe, traipses past the remains of a party to the front door. Opening it reveals a nice looking, nicely dressed woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A series of realizations is made by each of them, quickly, silently, ending up with Klonowska looking ill.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Who is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Schindler sets a cup of coffee down in front of his wife. Behind him, through a doorway, Klonowska can be seen hurriedly gathering her things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emilie begrudges him a glance to the bedroom, catching the girl just as she looks up -- embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His face is complete innocence. It's the first thing she fell in love with; and perhaps the thing that keeps her from killing him now. Klonowska emerges from the bedroom thoroughly self-conscious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shakes Emilie's limp hand. Schindler sees her to the door, lets her out and returns to the table, smiling to himself. Emilie's glancing around at the place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods; he's proud of it. He studies her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: She's so embarrassed -- look at her --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what, you'd like her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oskar, please -- SCHINDLER What -- EMILIE I don't have to like her just because you do. It doesn't work that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You would, though. That's what I'm saying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye. It was a pleasure meeting you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've done well here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You look great.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They emerge from the building in formal clothes, both of them looking great. It's wet and slick; the doorman offers Emilie his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doorman shoots a glance to Schindler that asks, clearly, Really? Schindler opens the passenger door of the Mercedes for his wife, and the doorman helps her in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Careful of the pavement -- SCHINDLER -- Mrs. Schindler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A nice place. "No Jews or Dogs Allowed." The maitre 'd welcomes the couple warmly, shakes Schindler's hand. Nodding to his date -- SCHINDLER Mrs. Schindler. The maitre 'd tries to bury his surprise. He's almost successful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - NIGHT No fewer than four waiters attend them -- refilling a glass, sliding pastries onto china, lighting Schindler's cigarette, raking crumbs from the table with little combs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She doesn't know, but she does know him. And all these signs of apparent success just don't fit his profile. Schindler lets her in on a discovery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He waits for her to guess what the thing is. His looks says, It's so simple, how can you not know?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's not a charade, all this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A charade? How could it be a charade?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's no way I could have known this before, but there was always something missing. In every business I tried, I see now it wasn't me that was failing, it was this thing, this missing thing. Even if I'd known what it was, there's nothing I could have done about it, because you can't create this sort of thing. And it makes all the difference in the world between success and failure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: War.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: loomy Sunday" from a combo on a stage. Schindler and Emilie dancing. Pressed against her -- both have had a few -- he can feel her laugh to herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles, even as his eyes roam the room and find and meet the eyes of a German girl dancing with another man.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I feel like an old-fashioned couple. It feels good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATER - NIGHT Schindler and Emilie lounging in bed, champagne bottle on the nightstand. Long silence before -- EMILIE Should I stay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not the answer she's looking for and he knows it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not it either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler stares out at the lights of the city. They look like jewels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He promises her nothing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (pause) It's a beautiful city.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Should I stay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause) It's up to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it's up to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Promise me no doorman or maitre 'd will presume I am anyone other than Mrs. Schindler... and I'll stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Emilie waves goodbye to him from a first-class compartment window. Down on the platform, he waves goodbye to her. as the train pulls away, he turns away, and the platform of the next track is revealed -- soldiers and clerks supervising the boarding of hundreds of people onto another train -- the image turning BLACK AND WHITE.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your luggage will follow you. Make sure it's clearly labeled. Leave your luggage on the platform.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .E.F. LOADING DOCK - DAY As workers load crates of enamelware onto trucks -- back to COLOR -- Stern and Schindler and the dock foreman confer over an invoice. More to Stern -- FOREMAN Every other time it's been all right. This time when I weigh the truck, I see he's heavy, he's loaded too much. I point this out to him, I tell him to wait, he tells me he's got a new arrangement with Mr. Schindler -- (to Schindler)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the surface, Schindler remains calm; underneath, he's livid. Clearly it's not "okay" with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern and Schindler exchange a glance. Then -- SCHINDLER (pause) You're sure. The foreman nods.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: that you know all about it and it's okay with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's "okay" with me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How heavy was he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not that much, just too much for it to be a mistake -- 200 kilos.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Pfefferberg and Schindler bang in through the front door, startling a woman at a desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They move past her without a word and into the back of the place, into a storeroom. They stride past long racks full of enamelware and other goods. A man glances up, sees them coming. He's one of Schindler's investors, the one who questioned the German's word. The man's teenage sons rush to their father's defense, but Pfefferberg grabs him and locks an arm tightly around his neck. Silence. Then, calmly -- SCHINDLER If you or anyone acting as an agent for you comes to my factory again, I'll have you arrested.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and walks away. Pfefferberg lets the guy go and follows. The investor's sons help their father up off the floor. Gasping, he yells.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Can I help you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was a mistake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was a mistake? What was a mistake? How do you know what I'm talking about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, it wasn't a mistake, but it was one time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We had a deal, you broke it. One phone call and your whole family is dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I gave you money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: but Schindler and Pfefferberg are already gone, coming through the front office and out the front door -- EXT. STOREFRONT - CONTINUOUS - DAY -- to the street. Pfefferberg looks a little shaken from the experience. Schindler straightens his friend's clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, then, Schindler can't imagine what could be wrong. He pats Pfefferberg on the shoulder and leads him away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How you feeling, all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter, everything all right at home? (Pfefferberg nods) Mila's okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The long tables accommodate most of workers. The rest eat their lunch on the floor. Soup and bread.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SAME TIME - DAY An elegant place setting for one. Meat, vegetables, glass of wine, all untouched. Schindler leafing through pages of a report Stern has prepared for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No chance of that. Satisfied, Schindler returns the report to his accountant and starts to eat. Stern knows he is excused, but looks like he wants to say something more; he just doesn't know how to say it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler gives his accountant a long-suffering look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler's silence says, Is this really necessary? Stern pretends it's a tacit okay, goes to the door and pokes his head out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An old man with one arm appears in the doorway and Schindler glances to the ceiling, to heaven. As the man slowly makes his way into the room, Schindler sees the bruises on his face. And when he speaks, only half his mouth moves; the other half is paralyzed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler shakes the man's hand perfunctorily and tells Stern with a look, okay, that's enough, get him out of here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler is dying, and telling Stern with his eyes, Get this guy out of here. Stern takes the man's arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They disappear out the door. Schindler sits down to his meal. And tries to eat it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I could try to read this or I could eat my lunch while it's till hot. We're doing well?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better this month than last?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Any reason to think next month will be worse?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The war could end.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (impatient) What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause) There's a machinist outside who'd like to thank you personally for giving him a job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He asks every day. It'll just take a minute. He's very grateful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Lowenstein?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to thank you, sir, for giving me the opportunity to work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're welcome, I'm sure you're doing a great job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The SS beat me up. They would have killed me, but I'm essential to the war effort, thanks to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's great.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I work hard for you. I'll continue to work hard for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's great, thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God bless you, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a good man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, Mr. Lowenstein.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He saved my life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, he did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God bless him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Stern and Schindler emerge from the rear of the factory. The Mercedes is waiting, the back door held open by a driver. Climbing in -- SCHINDLER Don't ever do that to me again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern knows what he means. And Schindler knows he knows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The driver closes the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Close the door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Snow on the ground and more coming down. A hundred of Schindler's workers marching past the ghetto gate, as is the custom, under armed guard. Turning onto Zablocie Street, they're halted by an SS unit standing around some trucks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shovels scraping at snow. The marchers working to clear it from the street. A dialog between one of the guards and an SS officer is interrupted by a shot -- and the face of the one-armed machinist falls into the frame.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Herman Toffel, an SS contact of Schindler's who he actually likes, sits behind his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler knows it's not Toffel's fault, but the whole situation is maddening to him. He shakes his head in disgust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler gets up, shakes Toffel's hand, turns to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Toffel nods, smiles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's got nothing to do with reality, Oskar, I know it and you know it, it's a matter of national priority to these guys. It's got a ritual significance to them, Jews shoveling snow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I lost a day of production. I lost a worker. I expect to be compensated.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: File a grievance with the Economic Office, it's your right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would it do any good?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you're going to have to put up with a lot of snow shoveling yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A one-armed machinist, Oskar?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (right back) He was a metal press operator, quite skilled.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: From a distance, Stern and Schindler slowly walk a wasteland that lies between the rear of DEF and two other factories -- a radiator works and a box plant. Stern's doing all the talking, in his usual quiet but persuasive manner. Every so often, Schindler, glancing from his own factory to the others, nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The party pins the two other German businessmen wear are nothing compared to the elaborate thing in Schindler's lapel. He sits at his desk sipping cognac, a large portrait of Hitler hanging prominently on the wall behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern, who has been keeping a low profile, hands the gentlemen each a set of documents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man glances to Stern, and back to Schindler, his look saying, This is wrong, having a Jew present while we discuss business. If Schindler catches his meaning, he doesn't admit it. Kuhnpast almost sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a long stunned silence. The Germans can't believe it. After the initial shock wears off, Kuhnpast has to laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody is kidding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sets it down, gets up. Hohne gets up. They return the documents to Stern and turn to leave. They aren't quite out the door when Schindler wonders out loud to Stern:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The businessmen slow, but don't look back into the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Unlike your radiators -- and your boxes -- my products aren't for sale on the open market. This company has only one client, the German Army. And lately I've been having trouble fulfilling my obligations to my client. With your help, I hope the problem can be solved. The problem, simply, is space.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like you to consider a proposal which I think you'll find equitable. I'd like you to think about it and get back to me as soon as -- KUHNPAST Excuse me -- do you really think this is appropriate?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can appreciate your problem. If I had any space I could lease you, I would. I don't. I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me neither, sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to lease your facilities, I want to buy them. I'm prepared to offer you fair market value. And to let you stay on, if you want, as supervisors. (pause) On salary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've got to be kidding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause) Thanks for the drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You try to be fair to people, they walk out the door; I've never understood that. What's next?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Christmas presents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Pfefferberg wipes a smudge from the hood of an otherwise pristine BMW Cabriolet. As Scherner and his wife emerge from their house in robes, Scherner whispers to himself -- SCHERNER Oskar...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Workers high on the side of the building toss down the letters of the radiator sign as others hoist up a big "D." Under armed guard, others unload a metal press machine from a truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Technicians make adjustments to presses already in place. Others test the new firing ovens. Kuhnpast is being forcibly removed from the premises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crowded beyond belief, the place is like a post office gone mad. Stern, moving along one of the impossibly crowded lines, pauses to speak with an elderly couple.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A hand slaps a blue sticker on a work card. Slap, another. And another. And another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .E.F. FRONT OFFICE - DAY Christmas decorations. Klonowska at her desk, her eyes closed tight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She opens her eyes and smiles. Schindler is holding a poodle in his arms. She comes around to kiss him. He sets the dog on the desk. Stern, across the room, watches blank-faced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler, Stern and Klonowska turn to the voice. Two Gestapo men have entered unannounced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler stares at them in disbelief. Stern quietly slips one of the ledgers on his desk into a drawer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He doesn't wait for their approval. He scribbles down some names -- Toffel, Czurda, Reeder, Scherner. Underlining Scherner, he glances to Klonowska. She understands.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Oskar Schindler?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have a warrant to take your company's business records with us. And another to take you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Am I permitted to have my secretary cancel my appointments for the day?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A humorless middle-level bureaucrat sits behind a desk and D.E.F.'s ledgers and cashbooks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man slowly shakes his head 'no' to Schindler's offer of a cigarette. Schindler tamps it against the crystal of his gold watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler lights the cigarette and drags on it, all but ignoring the man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The quiet matter-of-fact tone, more than the comment itself, throws the bureaucrat off his rhythm. His eyes narrow slightly. There's a long silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You live very well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This standard of living comes entirely from legitimate sources, I take it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As an SS supplier, you have a moral obligation to desist from blackmarket dealings. You're in business to support the war effort, not to fatten -- SCHINDLER (interrupting) You know? When my friends ask, I'd love to be able to tell them you treated me with the utmost courtesy and respect.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The two who arrested him lead Schindler down a long hallway. They reach a door, have him step inside and close the door after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler knocks on the inside of the door. A Waffen SS man opens it. The "prisoner" peels several bills from a thick wad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands the young guard five times the going price.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guard turns to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He peels off several more bills and hands them over.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Chances of getting a bottle of vodka pretty good?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a minute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pajamas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Perched on the side of the bed in pajamas, Schindler works on a breakfast of herring and eggs, cheeses, rolls and coffee. Someone has also brought him a newspaper. There's an apologetic knock on the door before it opens.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry to disturb you, sir. Whenever you're ready, you're free to leave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Schindler, the Gestapo clerk and one of the arresting officers cross the foyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler ignores the man completely. Reaching the front doors, the clerk turns over the D.E.F. records to their owner and offers his hand. Schindler lets it hang there.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'd advise you not to get too comfortable. Sooner or later, law prevails. No matter who your friends are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You expect me to walk home, or what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tightly) Bring a car around for Mr. Schindler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .E.F. FACTORY - DAY A Gestapo limousine pulls in through the gates of the factory, parks near the loading docks. The driver, the same SS officer, waits for Schindler to climb out, but he doesn't; he waits for the SS man to come around and open the door for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are no less than forty able-bodied Jewish laborers working on the docks, any one of which would be better suited to the task. The Gestapo man calls to one of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guy just stares. Finally he heads off with the ledgers. The poodle bounds out past him and over to Schindler. He gives the dog a pat on the head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If you'd return the ledgers to my office I'd appreciate it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me -- hey -- (the guy turns) They're working.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Elegantly dressed for a night out, Schindler and Klonowska emerge from the building. As they're escorted to the waiting car, Schindler hesitates. A nervous figure in the shadows of an alcove is gesturing to him, beckoning him. Schindler excuses himself. Klonowska watches as he joins the man in the alcove. Their whispered conversation is over quickly and the man hurries off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - NIGHT From the locomotive, looking back, the string of splattered livestock carriages stretches into darkness. There's a lot of activity on the platform. Guards mill. Handcards piled with luggage trundle by. People hand up children to others already in the cars and climb aboard after them. The clerks are out in full force with their lists and clipboards, reminding the travelers to label their suitcases. Climbing from his Mercedes, Schindler stares. He's heard of this, but actually seeing the juxtaposition -- human and cattle cars -- this is something else. Recovering, he tells Klonowska to stay in the car and, moving along the side of the train, calls Stern's name to the faces peering out from behind the slats and barbed wire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: several pages-worth on a clipboard; a Gestapo clerk methodically leafing through them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The clerk shows him the list, points out the name to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler pulls out a small notepad and drops his voice to a hard murmur, the growl of a reasonable man who isn't ready -- yet -- to bring out his heavy guns:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Schindler writes it down, the clerk has second thoughts and calls to a superior, an SS sergeant, who comes over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sergeant takes a good hard look at the clothes, at the pin, at the man wearing them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sergeant takes out a pad. Now all three of them have lists. He jots down Schindler's name. Schindler jots down his and flips the pad closed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks away, back toward his car. The clerk and sergeant smile. But slowly, slowly, the smiles sour at the possibility that this man calmly walking away from them could somehow arrange such a fate...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) He's essential. Without him, everything comes to a grinding halt. If that happens -- CLERK Itzhak Stern? (Schindler nods) He's on the list.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, let's find him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's on the list. If he were an essential worker, he would not be on the list. He's on the list. You can't have him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm talking to a clerk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, the list is correct.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't ask you about the list, I asked you your name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Klaus Tauber.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The gentleman thinks a mistake's been made.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My plant manager is somewhere on this train. If it leaves with him on it, it'll disrupt production and the Armaments Board will want to know why.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the clerk) Is he on the list?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Schindler) The list is correct, sir. There's nothing I can do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: May as well get your name while you're here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My name? My name is Kunder. Sergeant Kunder. What's yours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Schindler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sergeant, Mr. Tauber, thank you very much. I think I can guarantee you you'll both be in Southern Russia before the end of the month. Good evening.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Schindler, the clerk and the sergeant -- stride along the side of the cars. Two of them are calling out loudly -- CLERK & SERGEANT Stern! Itzhak Stern! Soon it seems as if everybody except Schindler is yelling out the name. As they reach the last few cars, the accountant's face appears through the slats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guards yank at a lever, slide the gate open. Stern climbs down. The clerk draws a line through his name on the list and hands the clipboard to Schindler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Schindler signs three or four forms, the guards slide the carriage gate closed. Those left inside seem grateful for the extra space.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler returns the clipboard. The sergeant motions to another who motions to the engineer. As the train pulls out, Stern tries to keep up with Schindler who's striding away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler silences him with a look. He's livid. Stern glances down at the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler turns away and heads for the car. Stern hurries after him. They pass an area where all the luggage, carefully tagged, has been left -- the image becoming BLACK and WHITE.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Open it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Initial it, please. (Schindler initials the change) And this...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It makes no difference to us, you understand -- this one, that one. It's the inconvenience to the list. It's the paperwork.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I somehow left my work card at home. I tried to tell them it was a mistake, but they --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. It was stupid. (contrite) Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mechanics' hood-lamps throw down pools of light through which me wheel handcarts piled high with suitcases, briefcases, steamer trunks -- BLACK and WHITE. Moving along with one of the handcarts into a huge garage past racks of clothes, each item tagged, past musical instruments, furniture, paintings, against one wall -- children's toys, sorted by size. The cart stops. A valise is handed to someone who dumps and sorts the contents on a greasy table. The jewelry is taken to another area, to a pit, one of two deep lubrication bays filled with watches, bracelets, necklaces, candelabra, Passover platters, gold in one, silver the other, and tossed in. At workbenches, four Jewish jewelers under SS guard sift and sort and weigh and grade diamonds, pearls, pendants, brooches children's rings -- faltering only once, when a uniformed figure upends a box, spilling out gold teeth smeared with blood -- the image saturating with COLOR.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fractured gravestones like broken teeth jut from the earth of a neglected Jewish cemetery outside of town. Down the road that runs alongside it comes a German staff car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the backseat, Untersturmfuhrer Amon Goeth pulls on a flask of schnapps. His age and build are about that of Schindler's; his face open and pleasant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other SS officers in the car -- Knude, Haase and Hujar -- aren't sure what he means. He's peering out the window at the tombstones.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Make a nice driveway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The staff car passes through the portals of the ghetto and down the trolley lines of Lwowska Street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the car slowly cruises through the ghetto, Knude, like a tour guide, briefs the new man, Goeth -- KNUDE This street divides the ghetto just about in half. On the right -- Ghetto A: civil employees, industry workers, so on. On the left, Ghetto B: surplus labor, the elderly mostly. Which is where you'll probably want to start. The look Goeth gives Knude tells him to refrain, if he would, from offering tactical opinions.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Of course that's entirely up to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Outside of town, a previously abandoned limestone quarry lies nestled between two hills. The stone and brick buildings look like they've been here forever; the wooden structures, those that are up, are built of freshly-cut lumber. There's a great deal of activity. New construction and renovation -- foundations being poured, rail tracks being laid, fences and watchtowers going up, heavy segments of huts -- wall panels, eaves sections -- being dragged uphill by teams of bescarved women like some ancient Egyptian industry. Goeth surveys the site from a knoll, clearly pleased with it. But then he's distracted by voices -- a man's, a woman's -- arguing down where some barracks are being erected. The woman breaks off the dialog with a disgusted wave of her hand and stalks back to a half-finished barracks. The man, one from the car, Hujar, sees Goeth, Knude and Haase coming down the hill and moves to meet them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth watches the woman moving around the shell of the building, pointing, directing, telling the workers to take it all down. He goes to take a closer look. She comes over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth considers the foundation as if he knew about such things. He nods pensively. Then turns to Hujar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's hard to tell which is more stunned by the order, the woman or Hujar. Both stare at Goeth in disbelief. He gives her the reason along with a shrug -- GOETH You argued with my man. (to Hujar) Shoot her. Hujar unholsters his pistol but holds it limply at his side. The workers become aware of what's happening and still their hammers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth groans and takes the gun from him and puts it to the woman's head. Calmly to her -- GOETH I'm sure you're right. He fires. She crumples to the ground. He returns the gun to his stunned inferior and, gesturing down at the body, addresses the workers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and walks away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: She says the foundation was poured wrong, she's got to take it down. I told her it's a barracks, not a fucking hotel, fucking Jew engineer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The entire foundation has to be dug up and re-poured. If it isn't, the thing will collapse before it's even completed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calmly) Shoot her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's somebody who knew what they were doing. That's somebody I needed. (pause) Take it down, re-pour it, rebuild it, like she said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Stable boys lead two horses into the pre-dawn light. The animals' hoofs shatter tufts of weeds like fingers of glass; fog plumes from their nostrils.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In addition to the exhaust from idling trucks and the curling smoke from the Sonderkommando units' cigarettes, there is excitement in the chilly pre-dawn air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An empty street. Rooftops against a lightening sky. A few of the windows in the buildings are lighted, glowing amber; the majority are still dark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The stable boys hoist saddles onto the horses, cinch the straps. Leaning against the hood of the Mercedes, Schindler and Ingrid, in long hacking jackets, riding breeches and boots, share cognac from his flask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Untersturmfuhrer Goeth, soon to be Commandant Goeth, stands before the assembled troops with a flask of cognac in his hand. He looks out over them proudly; they're good boys, these, the best. He addresses them -- GOETH Today is history. The young will ask with wonder about this day. Today is history and you are a part of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A fourteen year old kid hurries across to the square pulling on his O.D. armband. Several others of the Jewish Ghetto Police, Golberg among them, are already assembled there. The clerks, the list makers, scissor open their folding tables, set out their ink pads and stamps.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) When, elsewhere, they were footing the blame for the Black Death, Kazimierz the Great, so called, told the Jews they could come to Cracow. They came.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ingrid climbs onto one of the horses, Schindler onto the other. As the animals gallop away with their riders toward a wood, the stable boys wave.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) They trundled their belongings into this city, they settled, they took hold, they prospered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The fresh young faces of the Sonderkommandos, listening to their commander.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: For six centuries, there has been a Jewish Cracow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The horses panting hard. Their hoofs hammering at the ground, climbing a hill. Riding boots kicking at their flanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boots of Amon Goeth slowly pacing. He stops. Tight on his face, smiling pleasantly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: By this weekend, those six centuries, they're a rumor. They never happened. Today is history.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The galloping horses break through to a clearing high on a hill. The riders pull in the reins and the hoofs rip at the earth. Schindler smiles at the view, the beauty of it with the sun just coming up. From here, all of Cracow can be seen in striking relief, like a model of a town. He can see the Vistula, the river that separates the ghetto from Kazimierz; Wawel Castle, from where the National Socialist Party's Hans Frank rules the Government General of Poland; beyond it, the center of town. He begins to notice refinements: the walls that define the ghetto; Peace Square, the assembly of men and boys. He notices a line of trucks rolling east across the Kosciuscko Bridge, and another across the bridge at Podgorze, a third along Zablocie Street, all angling in on the ghetto like spokes to a hub.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wheels of the last truck clear the portals at Lwowska Street and the Sonderkommandos jump down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Families are routed from their apartments. An appeal to be allowed to pack is answered with a rifle butt; an unannounced move to a desk drawer is countered with a shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spilling out of the buildings, they're herded into lines without regard to family consideration; some other unfathomable system is at work here. The wailing protests of a woman to join her husband's line are abruptly cut off by a short burst of gunfire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From here, the action down below seems staged, unreal; the rifle bursts no louder than caps. Dismounting, Schindler moves closer to the edge of the hill, curious. His attention is drawn to a small distant figure, all in red, at the rear of one of the many columns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Small red shoes against a forest of gleaming black boots. A Waffen SS man occasionally corrects the little girl's drift, fraternally it seems, nudging her gently back in line with the barrel of his rifle. A volley of shots echoes from up the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler watches as the girl slowly wanders away unnoticed by the SS. Against the grays of the buildings and street she's like a moving red target.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A truck thundering down the street obscures her for a moment. Then she's moving past a pile of bodies, old people executed in the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler watches: she's so conspicuous, yet she keeps moving -- past crowds, past dogs, past trucks -- as though she were invisible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Patients in white gowns, and doctors and nurses in white, are herded out the doors of a convalescent hospital. The small figure in red moves past them. Shots explode behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Short bursts of light flash throughout the ghetto like stars. Schindler, fixated on the figure in red, loses sight of her as she turns a corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She climbs the stairs. The building is empty. She steps inside an apartment and moves through it. It's been ransacked. As she crawls under the bed, the scene DRAINS of COLOR. The gunfire outside sounds like firecrackers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence. Schindler and Ingrid are gone. Below, the ghetto lies like a void within the city, its perimeter and interior clearly distinguishable by darkness. Outside it, the lights of the rest of Cracow glimmer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .E.F. FACTORY - NIGHT Tables and tools and enamelware scrap. The metal presses and lathes, still. The firing ovens, cold. The gauges at zero. Against the wall of windows overlooking the empty factory floor stands a figure, Schindler, in silhouette against the glass, black against white, not moving, just staring down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bloody wheelbarrows, stark against the tree line of a forest above the completed forced labor camp, PLASZOW.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Names on lists. Names called out. Tight on faces. Goldberg at one of several folding tables. The gangsterturned -- ghetto-cop is now the Lord of Lists inside Plaszow. He and other listmakers call out names, accounting for those thousands who survived the liquidation of the ghetto and now stand before them in long straight rows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amon Goeth stirs, wakes, glances at the woman asleep beside him. Hungover, he drags himself slowly out of bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - MORNING Goeth steps out onto the balcony in his undershirt and shorts and peers out across the labor camp, his labor camp, his kingdom. Satisfied with it, even amazed, he's reminiscent of Schindler looking down on his kingdom, his factory, as he loves to do, from his wall of glass. Life is great. Goeth reaches for a rifle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PLASZOW SAME TIME - MORNING Workers loading quarry rock onto trolleys under Ukrainian guard and a low morning sun. Every so often, one glances with anticipation to the balcony of Goeth's "villa" -- which is in fact nothing more than a two-story stone house perched on a slight rise in the dry landscape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The butt of the rifle against his shoulder, Goeth aims down at the quarry -- at this worker, at that one -- indiscriminately, inscrutably. He fires a shot and a distant figure falls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SAME TIME - MORNING The woman in bed groans at the echoing shot. She's used to it but she still hates it; it's such an awful way to be woken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She buries her head under a pillow. Goeth reappears. He pads to his bathroom, goes inside and urinates.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (mutters) Amon... Christ...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Schindler's Mercedes winds through the camp, past warehouses and workshops, trucks full of furs and furniture, work details, barracks, guard blocks. A man standing alone wears a sign around his neck -- "I am a potato thief."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Mercedes pulls in next to some other nice cars parked on a driveway made of tombstones from the Jewish cemetery.
direction.name: direction
