direction.raw_text: A patio table set with crystal, china, silver. Goeth and Hujar are there, in pressed SS uniforms, and two industrialists, Bosch and Madritsch. One chair is empty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hujar glances off, interrupted by Schindler's arrival. Although he's never been here, the industrialist comes in like he owns the place. All but Goeth rise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He works his way around the table, patting Bosch and Madritsch on the back -- he knows them -- shaking Hujar's hand, who he doesn't know. He reaches Goeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth takes a good long look at the handsomely dressed entrepreneur and allows him to shake his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler takes a seat, shakes a napkin onto his lap, nods to the servant holding out a bottle of champagne to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth watches him. The others watch Goeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler clearly doesn't care, but nods as though he did. He drinks. Goeth just watches him with what seems to be growing amusement. He nods to Hujar to continue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler laughs out loud, cutting Hujar off. Hujar glances over to Goeth nonplussed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not sorry at all, and starts in on the plate of food that's set down in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth slowly shakes his head no... then smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shrugs like, those are the breaks, too bad. Goeth just smiles. The others watch the two of them, unsure how they're supposed to react.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your machinery will be moved and installed by the SS at no cost to you. You will pay no rent, no maintenance --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, come on, sit --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We started without you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I miss anything important?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was explaining to Mr. Bosch and Mr. Madritsch some of the benefits of moving their factories into Plaszow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, good, yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Since your labor is housed on-site, it's available to you at all times. You can work them all night if you want. Your factory policies, whatever they've been in the past, they'll continue to be, they'll be respected --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, they told me you were going to be trouble -- Czurda and Scherner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're kidding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He looks great, though, doesn't he? I have to know -- where do you get a suit like that? what is that, silk? (Schindler nods) It's great.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd say I'd get you one but the guy who made it, he's probably dead, I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY The others have gone. It's just Goeth and Schindler now. Goeth pours glasses of cognac.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler nods pensively, perhaps in agreement, perhaps at some other thought. There's a silence, broken finally by -- SCHINDLER I go to work the other day, there's nobody there. Nobody tells me about this, I have to find out, I have to go in, everybody's gone -- GOETH They're not gone, they're here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His voice echoes into silence. An acquiescent shrug from Goeth finally. And a nod; Schindler's right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler pours himself another shot from the bottle, nurses it. He's in a foul mood. They study each other, trying to determine perhaps who's more powerful. Eventually -- GOETH Scherner told me something else about you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth tries to put the situation in perspective:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler admits it by not disagreeing. Goeth thinks about it, nods to himself again, then frowns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth mulls it over, his shrug saying "maybe, maybe not." A silence before -- SCHINDLER I'd be grateful. There's the word Goeth was waiting to hear.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Something wonderful's happened, do you know what it is? Without planning it, we've reached that happy point in our careers where duty and financial opportunity meet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're mine!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every day that goes by, I'm losing money. Every worker that is shot, costs me money -- I have to get somebody else, I have to train them -- GOETH We're going to be making so much money, none of this is going to matter -- SCHINDLER (cutting him off) It's bad business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs) Some of the boys went crazy, what're you going to do? You're right, it's bad business, but it's over with, it's done. (pause) Occasionally, sure, okay, you got to make an example. But that's good business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, what's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That you know the meaning of the word gratitude. That it's not some vague thing with you like with some guys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: True.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want to stay where you are. You got things going on the side, things are good, you don't want anybody telling you what to do -- I can understand all that. (pause) What you want is your own sub-camp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you have any idea what's involved? The paperwork alone? Forget you got to build it all, getting the fucking permits, that's enough to drive you crazy. Then the engineers show up. They stand around and they argue about drainage -- I'm telling you, you'll want to shoot somebody, I've been through it, I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you've been through it. You know. You could make things easier for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .E.F. SUBCAMP SITE - DAY An SS surveyor, with even paces, measures a distance of the bare field adjacent to the factory. He sticks a little flag into the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .E.F. SUBCAMP SITE - DAY A watchtower, half-erected, the little flag still in the ground. Laborers hammer at it while others roll out barbed wire fencing. A surveyor supervises the placement of a post and carefully measures its heights; it has to be nine feet, exactly. At a folding table in the middle of the field, Schindler signs checks made out to the Construction Office, Plaszow -- requisitioning more lumber, cement and hardware.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Plaszow prisoners load the requisitioned building supplies -- the lumber, cement and hardware -- onto trucks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WAREHOUSE, CRACOW - DAY The trucks parked not at Schindler's sub-camp, but at the loading dock of Goeth's private warehouse in Cracow. Inside the building can be glimpsed all kinds of Plaszow goods: clothes, food, construction equipment, furniture. Checkbook laid out on the hood of his Mercedes, Schindler pays for the requested materials a second time -- this time with a check made out to Amon Goeth personally -- and hands it over to his bagman, Hujar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .E.F. SUBCAMP FIELD - DAY Some SS architects groan over a set of blueprints. Schindler and an SS officer walk by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shrugs, Too bad, what're you going to do? The SS guy has to think. Yeah, that's a problem. Two huge leashed dogs yank another SS man across their path.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You have the Poles beat the Czechs, you have the Czechs beat the Poles, that way everybody stays in line.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All I have is Jews.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .E.F. - DAY As five hundred Plaszow prisoners are marched back onto the grounds of D.E.F., any hope they may have had of a more lenient environment is quickly dashed. The place -- completed -- looks like a fortress: barbed-wire, towers, SS guards and dogs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .E.F. FACTORY - DAY Where once they glimpsed the not too threatening figure of Oskar Schindler strolling through the factory, the workers who dare glance up now find armed guards moving past. And further up, behind the wall of windows, Schindler moving around, entertaining SS officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Rosner brothers in evening clothes, Leo on accordion, Henry on violin, playing a Strauss melody, trying to keep it muted, inoffensive. Few of the guests pay attention, which is fine with them. An SS officer chats with Schindler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler, with yet another girl on his arm, endures the officer's lies while sweeping the room with his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler looks at him for the first time, knowingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler's girl excuses herself to get a drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler nods, Done. Both watch his date across the room getting a drink. As usual, she's the best-looking on there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever tolerance Schindler's had up to this point with John leaves his face; the looks he gives him now is pure contempt.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: she's seventy years old, she's been there forever -- they bomb her house. Everything's gone. The furniture, everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (well aware the man is lying) Thank God she wasn't there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was thinking maybe you could help her out. Some plates and mugs, some stew pots, I don't know. Say half a gross of everything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She run an orphanage, your aunt?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's old. What she can't use maybe she can sell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want it sent directly to her or through you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Through me, I think. I'd like to enclose a card.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your wife must be a saint.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATER - NIGHT Goeth's girl tonight, a Pole, eighteen, nineteen, places a hand on Schindler's sleeve. They're at the important end of the large table with Goeth, along with Czurda and Leo John and their girlfriends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another round of laughs, only this time it's forced. Everybody knows it's true, but you don't say it out loud, and Schindler knows better. Goeth gives him a look; they'll talk later.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're not a soldier?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a picture. Private Schindler? Blanket around his shoulders over in Kharkov?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Happened to what's his name -- up in Warsaw -- and he was bigger than you, Oskar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Toebbens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Happened to Toebbens. Almost. Himmler goes up to Warsaw, tells the armament guys, "Get the fucking Jews out of Toebbens' factory and put Toebbens in the army," and -- "and sent him to the Front." I mean, the Front.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's true. Never happen in Cracow, though, we all love you too much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I pay you too much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATER - NIGHT Goeth finds Schindler alone outside smoking a cigarette. Schindler acknowledges him, but that's about it. Finally -- SCHINDLER You held back Stern. You held back the one man most important to my business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth heads back inside. Schindler stays outside, finishing his cigarette.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He's important to my business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want for him, I'll give it to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want him. (turning back) Come on, let's go inside, let's have a good time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATER - NIGHT A folding table outside the prisoners' barracks. At it, playing cards, two night sentries. A figure appears out of the darkness. Schindler. He sets down on the table a fifth of vodka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - NIGHT Stern, summoned from his barracks, watches as Schindler digs through his coat pockets. Nearby, at the table, drinking now, the sentries. From the hill, the villa, the Rosners' music, faint, can be heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He discreetly hands over to the accountant some cigars scavenged from the party. From another pocket, he retrieves and hands over some tins of food -- all valuable commodities. From another pocket, perhaps not so valuable, but then who knows, a gold lighter. Regarding this last item -- SCHINDLER This, I don't know, maybe you can trade it for something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler shrugs, It's the least I can do. The two stand around a moment more before Schindler shrugs again, Sorry I can't do more. He reaches out, pats Stern on the shoulder, and, turning to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler comes back, but, out of embarrassment or -- maybe he wants to get back to the party -- waits with some impatience for Stern to tell whatever it is he wants to tell him. Lowering his voice -- STERN There's a guy. This thing happened. Goeth came into the metalworks -- CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got to go, I'll see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oskar --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Goeth moves through the crowded metalworks like a goodnatured foreman, nodding to this worker, wishing that one a good morning. He seems satisfied, even pleased, with the level of production. Goldberg is with him. They reach a particular bench, a particular worker, and Goeth smiles pleasantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not daring to look up, all the worker sees of Goeth is the starched cuff of his shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rabbi-turned-metalworker gestures with his head to a pile of hinges on the floor. Goeth nods. And in a tone more like a friend than anything else -- GOETH I got some workers coming in tomorrow... Where the hell they from again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shrugs apologetically and pulls out a pocket watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Goeth times him, Rabbi Levartov works at making a hinge as though his life depended on it -- which it does -- cutting the pieces, wrenching them together, smoothing the edges, all the while keeping count on his head of the seconds ticking away. He finishes and lets it fall onto the others on the floor. Forty seconds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again the rabbi works feverishly -- cutting, crimping, sanding, hearing the seconds ticking in his head -- and finishing in thirty-five. Goeth nods, impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He understands perfectly. So does Levartov; he has just crafted his own death in exactly 75 seconds. Goeth stands him against the workshop wall and adjusts his shoulders. He pulls out his pistol, puts it to the rabbi's head and pulls the trigger... click.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annoyed, Goeth extracts the bullet-magazine, slaps it back in and puts the barrel back to the man's head. He pulls the trigger again... and again there's a click.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He slams the weapon across Levartov's face and the rabbi slumps dazed to the floor. Looking up into Goeth's face, he knows it's not over. As Goeth walks away -- CUT BACK TO:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What are you making?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hinges, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yugoslavia.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yugoslavia. I got to make room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Make me a hinge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Another.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's very good. What I don't understand, though, is -- you've been working since what, about six this morning? Yet such a small pile of hinges?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mumble) Christ --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God damn it --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Tight on Schindler, a pensive nod, then a shrug.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The guy can turn out a hinge in less than a minute? Why the long story?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .E.F. - DAY Rabbi Levartov, brought over to D.E.F., works at a table with several others. As Schindler strolls by, the rabbi dares to speak -- LEVARTOV Thank you, sir. Schindler has to think a moment before he can figure out who the grateful man is.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yeah. You're welcome.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A dead chicken dangling from Hujar's hand, evidence of some kind. Goeth slowly pacing before a work detail of twenty or so men standing still, silent, in a row.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one confesses. Goeth nods, All right, takes a rifle from a guard and shoots one of the workers at random. With this added incentive, he waits for someone to tell him who stole the chicken. No one does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shrugs, Okay, points the rifle at another worker -- and a boy of fourteen, shuddering and weeping, steps out of line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth goes over to the boy, and, like a distant relative to a small child, tries to get him to look at his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy nods, weeps, screams -- BOY Him! He's pointing at the dead man. And Goeth astonishes the entire assembly of workers and guards by believing the boy. He returns the rifle to the guard and walks away. Hujar stares after him, then knowingly at the boy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody knows who stole the chicken. A man walks around with a chicken, nobody notices this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Still nobody knows.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There we go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was you? You committed this crime?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know who, though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A truck being loaded with supplies. Schindler signs for it and, appearing as rushed as he always does, returns the clipboard to Stern.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, sure, bring him over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .E.F. - DAY Schindler comes down the stairs with Klonowska. As they're crossing through the factory -- BOY Thank you, sir.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (distracted) That's okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A mechanic peering under the hood of Goeth's Adler. Leaning in he accidentally knocks a wrench off the radiator into the fan and there's an awful clatter before the engine dies. The mechanic glances up horrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As servants hoist a heavy, elaborately tooled saddle from Schindler's trunk - a gift for Goeth -- Schindler sees Stern coming toward him and glances skyward long-sufferingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .E.F. - DAY The mechanic, making adjustments to a metal press, glances up as Schindler moves past.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank -- SCHINDLER Yeah, yeah, yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .E.F. FACTORY - DAY Across the street stands a nervous young woman in a faded dress. She seems to be trying to summon the courage to cross over and onto the factory grounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .E.F. FACTORY - DAY Just inside the factory, she waits as a guard telephones Schindler's office. She can see the wall of windows from where she's standing, and Schindler himself as he appears at it, phone to his ear. He glances down at her disapprovingly and the guard hangs up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He won't see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The woman alone in a dismal room pulling on nylon stockings. At a mirror, she applies make-up. She slips into a provocative dress. Puts on heels. A Parisian hat. And looks in the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .E.F. - DAY Schindler waits for her on the landing of the stairs. He doesn't recognize her, but smiles to counter the unfortunately possibility she's some old girlfriend he's forgotten. Reaching him, she offers her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can tell now she doesn't know him. He seems relieved. He leads her past Klonowska's desk and into his office.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Krause.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He arranges a chair for her, goes to his liquor cabinet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pours himself a drink, warms it in his hands, smiles, clearly take with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The grace with which she's carried herself up to this point seems to evaporate as she struggles to find the words she wants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler's face changes like a wall going up, a mask of indifference like in the portrait of Adolf Hitler on the wall behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler glances away from her. He seems weary suddenly, depressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler glances back at her, his face hard, cold, and studies her for a long, long moment before -- SCHINDLER I don't do that. You've been misled. I ask one thing: whether or not a worker has certain skills. That's what I ask and that's what I care about, get out of my office. She stares at him, frightened and bewildered. She feels tears welling up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hurries out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Pernod? Cognac?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They say that no one dies here. They say your factory is a haven. They say you are good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who says that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everyone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My name is Regina Perlman, not Elsa Krause. I've been living in Cracow on false papers since the ghetto massacre. (pause) My parents are in Plaszow. They're old. They're killing old people in Plaszow now. They bury them up in the forest. I have no money. I borrowed these clothes. Will you bring them here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cry and I'll have you arrested, I swear to God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Schindler barges into Stern's office. In a foul and aggressive mood, he dispenses with pleasantries in order to admonish the accountant -- SCHINDLER People die, it's a fact of life. Stern has hardly had time to look up from the work on his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern's look is all innocence, but Schindler knows better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence. Schindler tries to settle down. Then -- SCHINDLER You have to understand, Goeth's under enormous pressure. You have to think of it in his situation. He's got this whole place to run, he's responsible for everything that goes on here, all these people -- he's got a lot of things to worry about. And he's got the war. Which brings out the worst in people. Never the good, always the bad. Always the bad. But in normal circumstances, he wouldn't be like this. He'd be all right. There'd be just the good aspects of him. Which is a wonderful crook. A guy who loves good food, good wine, the ladies, making money...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it isn't Stern who needs convincing; it's Schindler himself. It's doubtful he even realizes this, but it's clear to Stern. Schindler sighs either at the predicament itself, or at the fact that he's allowed Stern to place him right in the middle of it. He turns to leave, hesitates. He conducts a mental search for a name and eventually comes up with it:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He unstraps his watch, hands it to Stern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He wants to kill everybody? Great. What am I supposed to do, bring everybody over? Is that what you think? Yeah, send them over to Schindler, send them all. His place is a "haven," didn't you know? It's not a factory, it's not an enterprise of any kind, it's a haven for people with no skills whatsoever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think I don't know what you're doing? You're so quiet all the time? I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with concern) Are you losing money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm not losing money, that's not the point.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What other point is -- SCHINDLER (interrupts; yells) It's dangerous. It's dangerous, to me, personally.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And killing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll admit it's a weakness. I don't think he enjoys it. (pause) All right, he does enjoy it, so what? What do you expect me to do about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's nothing you can do. I'm not asking you to do anything. You came into my office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perlman, husband and wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give it to Goldberg, have him send them over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Distant music, Brahms' lullaby, from the Rosner Brothers way down by the women's barracks calming the inhabitants. Up here on the balcony, Schindler and Goeth, the latter so drunk he can barely stand up, stare out over Goeth's dark kingdom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It seems almost as though this temptation toward restraint, this image Schindler has brush-stroked of the merciful emperor, holds some appeal to Goeth. Perhaps, as he stares out over his camp, he imagines himself in the role, wondering what the power Schindler describes might feel like. Eventually, he glances over drunkenly, and almost smiles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They don't fear us because we have the power to kill, they fear us because we have the power to kill arbitrarily. A man commits a crime, he should know better. We have him killed, we feel pretty good about it. Or we kill him ourselves and we feel even better. That's not power, though, that's justice. That's different than power. Power is when we have every justification to kill -- and we don't. That's power. That's what the emperors had. A man stole something, he's brought in before the emperor, he throws himself down on the floor, he begs for mercy, he knows he's going to die... and the emperor pardons him. This worthless man. He lets him go. That's power. That's power.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Amon the Good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A stable boy works to ready Goeth's horse before he arrives. He sticks a bridle into its mouth, throws a riding blanket onto its back, drags out the saddle Schindler bought Goeth. Before he can finish, though, Goeth is there. The boy tries to hide his panic; he knows others have been shot for less.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Goeth waits, patiently it seems, whistling to himself, the stable boy tries to mask his confusion.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, sir, I'm almost done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, that's all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Goeth gallops around his great domain holding himself high in the saddle. But everywhere he looks, it seems, he's confronted with stoop-shouldered sloth. He forces himself to smile benevolently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth comes into his bedroom sweating from his ride. A worker with a pail and cloth appears in the bathroom doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to report, sir, I've been unable to remove the stains from your bathtub. Goeth steps past him to take a look. The worker is almost shaking, he's so terrified of the violent reprisal he expects to receive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The worker hasn't a defense for himself. Goeth's hand drifts down as if by instinct to the gun in his holster. He stares at the worker. He so wants to shoot him he can hardly stand it, right here, right in the bathroom, put some more stains on the porcelain. He takes a deep breath to calm himself. Then gestures grandly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The worker hurries out with his pail and cloth. Goeth just stands there for several moments -- trying to feel the power of emperors he's supposed to be feeling. But he doesn't feel it. All he feels is stupid.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What are you using?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Soap, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (incredulous) Soap? Not lye?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead, go on, leave. I pardon you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - DAY The worker hurries across the dying lawn outside the villa. He dares a glance back, and at that moment, a hand with a gun appears out the bathroom window and fires.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sentries at their little table again, drinking Schindler's vodka. Nearby, Schindler and Stern outside Stern's barracks. The accountant's tone is hushed:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If he didn't steal so much, I could hide it. If he's steal with some discretion...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Goldberg delivers a stack of requisitions and invoices, and leaves without a word. Behind his desk, Stern takes a cursory look at them and shakes his head in dismay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MINUTES LATER - DAY Stern comes in with the requisitions. Now it's Goldberg's turn to shake his head in dismay; he doesn't want to hear it -- STERN There are fifteen thousand people here -- GOLDBERG Goeth says there's twenty-five.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There are fifteen. He wants to say sixteen, seventeen, all right, maybe he can get away with it, but ten thousand over? It's stupid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stern, do me a favor, get out of here. You want to argue about it, go tell Goeth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Stern watches truck being unloaded of bags of flour, rice and other supplies. Goeth nods to Hujar. Hujar calls a halt. The workers climb down, close up the trucks. And, still half full, the trucks rumble off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: EXT. CRACOW - DAY The trucks at the loading dock of Goeth's private warehouse. Polish workers, under Hujar's supervision, throwing down the "surplus" bags of flour and rice -- the supplies for the phantom 10,000 prisoners.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) The SS auditors keep coming around, looking over the books -- Goeth knows this --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: you'd think he'd have the common sense to see what's coming. No, he steals with complete impunity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - CONTINUED - NIGHT They can see Goeth's villa up on the hill; figures moving around behind the windows. There's another party going on up there. Down here, as he nurses a drink from his flask, Schindler thinks about what Stern has told him, and eventually shrugs, Fine, fuck him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Stern slowly shakes his head 'no.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's the irony -- bad as it is, evil as Goeth is, it could get worse. Schindler understands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands over to Stern some negotiable items and leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So you'll be rid of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If Plaszow is closed, they'll have to send us somewhere else. Where -- who knows? Gross-Rosen maybe. Maybe Auschwitz.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll talk to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think it's too late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'll talk to somebody. I'll take care of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Schindler and Senior SS Officers Toffel and Scherner share a table in same smoke-filled nightclub they met in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler glances away to the floor show, nods to himself. Glancing back again, he considers the SS men with great sobriety.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His thinly veiled threat of exposure escapes neither SS man. The air seems thicker suddenly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The threat still stands, despite Schindler's assurance otherwise, and they all know it. So does Scherner's threat back to him, and they all know that, too. But Schindler just grins, and, glancing away -- SCHINDLER Come on, let's watch the girls.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's he done that's so bad -- take money? That's a crime? Come on, what are we here for, to fight a war? We're here to make money, all of us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's taking money and there's taking money, you know that. He's taking money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The place produces nothing. I shouldn't say that -- nothing it produces reaches the Army. That's not all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So I'll talk to him about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's a friend of yours, you want to help him out. Tell me this, though -- has he ever once shown you his appreciation? I've yet to see it. Never a courtesy. Never a thank you note. He forgets my wife at Christmas time -- SCHINDLER He's got no style, we all know that. So, we should hang him for it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's stealing from you, Oskar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course he's stealing from me, we're in business together. What is this? I'm sitting here, suddenly everybody's talking like this is something bad. We take from each other, we take from the Army, everybody uses everybody, it works out, everybody's happy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not like him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well, in some eyes it doesn't matter the amount we steal, it's that we do it. Each of us sitting at this table.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He doesn't deserve your loyalty. More important, he's not worth you making threats against us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did I threaten anybody here? I stated a simple fact.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .E.F. FACTORY - DAY In addition to the mid-day soup and break, there are bowls of fruit on the long work tables. At one of them, several workers are debating which of them will go upstairs to thank Schindler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .E.F. - SAME TIME - DAY In honor of Schindler's birthday, Goeth has brought over Stern and the Rosners -- the musicians, at the moment, accompanying the best baritone in the Ukrainian garrison. Surrounded by his friends and lovers, Schindler cuts a cake. He receives congratulations from the many SS men present and the embraces, in turn, of Ingrid and Klonowska and Goeth. From Stern he gets a handshake. A Jewish girl from the shop floor is admitted and timidly approaches the drunken group around Schindler. The SS men consider her as a curiosity; Schindler, as he would any beautiful girl. The music breaks and out of the silence comes a small nervous voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hesitates. She's surrounded by SS uniforms and swastikas and holstered guns. Schindler smiles; this is a beautiful girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He kisses her on the mouth. The smiles on the faces around them strain. Stern glances to heaven. Amon cocks his head like a confused dog. The kiss is broken, finally, and Schindler smiles again with impunity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girl backs away nodding anxiously; all she wants now is out before someone -- her, Schindler, both of them -- gets shot. Henry Rosner nudges Leo and they begin another song. And the party tries to resume.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...On behalf of the workers... sir... I wish you a happy birthday...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank them for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Were they not asleep in their barracks, the prisoners would no doubt shudder at the sight: the clerks are setting up their folding tables. Other figures move around the parade ground in the murky dawn light: these raising a banner, those wheeling filing cabinets across the Appellplatz, this one wiring a phonograph, that one saturating a pad with ink from a bottle. Goldberg, Lord of Lists, moves from table to table handing out carbons of lists and sharing morning pleasantries with the clerks. Some men in white appear like ghosts. A doctor's kid is opened, a stethoscope removed. Another cleans the lenses of his glasses. Someone sharpens a pencil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A trainman waving a lantern guides an engineer who's slowly backing an empty cattle car along the tracks. It couples to another empty slatted car with a harsh clank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The needle of the phonograph is set down on a pocked 78. The first scratchy note of a Strauss waltz blare from the camp speakers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In his undershirt and shorts Goeth calmly smokes his first cigarette of the morning as he listens to the music wafting up from down below. Down there on the Appellplatz, the entire population of the camp has been concentrated, some fifteen thousand prisoners.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Though the music and banners struggle to evoke a country fair, the presence of the doctors belie it. A sorting out process is going on here, the healthy from the unhealthy. A physician wipes at his brow with his handkerchief as several prisoners run back and forth, naked, before him. He makes his selections quickly: this one into this line, that one into that, and Goldberg moves them recording the names. Other groups of people run naked in front of other doctors and clerks. Notations are made and lines are formed. The sun beats down and the music lies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some still pulling their clothes back on, the first wave of the "unfit" is marched onto the platform. A guard slides open the gate of a cattle car and this first unlucky group climbs aboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Behind the camouflage of other women prisoners, Mila Pfefferberg rubs a beet against her cheeks in desperate hope of adding a little color to her skin. Amon Goeth, his shirtsleeves uncharacteristically rolled up, chats with one of the doctors as another group strips. Whether the topic is this Health Aktion or the unseasonable weather is unclear, but he nods approvingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth glances up, finds Poldek among the group taking off their clothes. Pfefferberg appeals to him with a look that asks, Do I really have to go through this, and Goeth turns to a clerk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pfefferberg is motioned away from the others; he's okay, he doesn't have to be put through this indignity. He calls out to the Commandant again -- PFEFFERBERG What about my wife? Goeth thinks about it a moment before he nods, Yeah, okay, sure. A clerk accompanies Pfefferberg and, making a notation on the way, finds Mila.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Commandant, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My mechanic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The sun is higher, the cattle cars hotter. Prisoners' arms stretch out between the slats offering diamonds in exchange for a sip of water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY The needle of the phonograph is set down on another record, a children's song, "Mammi, kauf mir ein Pferdchen" (Mommy, buy me a pony). Children are yanked from the arms of their parents. Wailing protests quickly escalate to brawls with the guards. Revolvers and rifles aim at the sun and fire. Music, shots, wails.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SAME TIME - DAY Guards traipse through a deserted barracks peering up at the rafters, pulling planks from the floor, upending cots, looking for some children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SAME TIME - DAY A small figure in red sprints across to another barracks, past it, to a crude wooden structure beyond it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SAME TIME - DAY An arm held out to either side, the small girl lowers herself into a pit into which men have defecated. She works her way slowly down, trying to find knee and toeholds on the foul walls, ignoring the flies invading her ears, her nostrils. Reaching the surface of the muck she lets her feet submerge, then her ankles, her shins, her knees, before finally touching harder ground. As she struggles to slow her breathing, her racing heart, she hears a hallucinatory murmur -- BOY'S VOICE This is our place. She sees eyes in the darkness; five other children are already there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY Waves of heat rise from the roofs of the long string of cattle cars. Inside, those who "failed" the medical exams bake as they wait for the last cars to be filled. Schindler's Mercedes pulls up. He climbs out and stares transfixed. He notices Goeth then, standing with the other industrialists, Bosch and Madritsch, and strolls over to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances away at the train. The idling engine only partially covers the desperate pleas for water coming from inside the slatted cars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grins. Schindler watches as another car is loaded. It's like they're climbing into an oven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth stares at him blankly, then with a What-will-you-think- of-next? kind of look, then laughs uproariously and calls over to Hujar -- GOETH Bring the fire trucks!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hujar heard him, he just doesn't get it. Finally he turns to another guy and tells him to do it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I tried to call you, I'm running a little late, this is taking longer than I thought. Have a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's going on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got a shipment of Hungarians coming in, I got to make room for them. It's always something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're complaining now? They don't know what complaining is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you say we get your fire brigade out here and hose down the cars?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: onto the scalding rooftops. The fire trucks are there, the hoses firing the cold water at the cars on the people inside who are roaring their gratitude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And amusing, not just to Goeth, but to the other SS officers standing around as well. Oskar moves away to talk with one of the firemen. At full extension, apparently the hoses still only reach halfway down the long line of cars. He returns to Goeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth finds this especially sidesplitting, and hollers -- GOETH Hujar!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is really cruel, Oskar, you're giving them hope. You shouldn't do that, that's cruel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got some 200-meter hoses back at D.E.F., we can reach the cars down at the end.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .E.F. HOSES have arrived and are being coupled to Plaszow's. As the water drenches the cars further back, the people inside loudly voice their thanks, and the guards and officers outside grin at the spectacle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The joke takes on new dimension when, from the back of the D.E.F. trucks, boxes of food are unloaded. Accompanied by the laughter of the SS, Schindler moves along the string of cars pushing sausages through the slats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth is almost hysterical. But slowly then, slowly, the amusement on his face fades. His friend moving along the cars bringing futile mercy to the doomed in front of countless SS men, laughing or not, is not just behaving recklessly here, it's as though he were possessed. The water rains down on the last car.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What does he think he's saving them from?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, my God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .E.F. - DAY A German staff car pulls in across the factory gate, blocking it. Two Gestapo men climb out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .E.F. FACTORY - DAY The girl who brought Schindler best wishes on his birthday glances up from her work to the Gestapo crossing through the factory. They climb the stairs to the upstairs offices and, moments later, appear behind Schindler's wall of glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler leaning against his desk, drink in his hand, calmly tries to assess his humorless arresters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler glances beyond them to a point outside his office, to Klonowska. She nods, she knows what to do, she'll make the phone calls, call in the favors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He snuffs out his cigarette.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not saying you'll regret it, but you might. I want you to be aware of that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll risk it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, sure, it's a nice day, I'll go for a drive with you guys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Settled comfortably in the backseat, Schindler glances idly out the window. As the car makes a turn, though, he looks back. Apparently he expected it to turn the other way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guys up front don't answer. Concern, for the first time, registers on Schindler's face. The car approaches a building block long with an ominous sameness to the windows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where are we going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Schindler is made to empty his pockets, his money, cigarettes, everything. Around him clerks speak in whispers, as if raised voices might set off head-splitting echoes along the narrow monotonous corridors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's led down a flight of stairs into a claustrophobic tunnel. He's taken past darkened cells. Past shadowy figures crouched in corners and on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A water bucket. A waste bucket. No windows. This is not a cell for dignitaries; this arrest is different. Schindler, incongruous with the dank surroundings in his double-breasted suit, slowly paces back and forth before his cellmate, a soldier who looks like he's been here forever, his greatcoat pulled up around his ears for warmth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler forces a smile. His cellmate just stares. Now there's a crime; much more impressive, much more serious, than his own.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I violated the Race and Resettlement Act. Though I doubt they can point out the actual provision to me. (pause) I kissed a Jewish girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In a stiff-backed chair sits a very unlikely defender of racial improprieties -- Amon Goeth. To an impassive SS colonel behind a desk, Goeth tries to highlight extenuating circumstances:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth tries to read the guy behind the desk, but his face is like a wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth shifts in his chair; he knows he's not getting anywhere with this guy. He switches tacts:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the silence that follows, Goeth realizes he has made a serious error in judgment. This man sitting soberly before him is one of that rare breed -- the unbribable official.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly the man stands up and salutes, which thoroughly confuses Goeth since Goeth is his inferior in rank. But he isn't saluting Goeth, he's saluting the officer who has just stepped into the room behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The colonel sits back down. Scherner pulls up a chair next to Goeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scherner smiles and allows Goeth to shake his hand, but it's clear, even to Goeth himself, that he has fallen from grace.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He likes women. He likes good-looking women. He sees a good-looking woman, he doesn't think. This guy has so many women. They love him. He's married, he's got all these women. All right, she was Jewish, he shouldn't have done it. But you didn't see this girl. I saw this girl. This girl was very good-looking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They cast a spell on you, you know, the Jews. You work closely with them like I do, you see this. They have this power, it's like a virus. Some of my men are infected with this virus. They should be pitied, not punished. They should receive treatment, because this is as real as typhus. I see this all the time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a matter of money? We can discuss that. That'd be all right with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're offering me a bribe?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "bribe?" No, no, please come on... a gratuity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sit down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Amon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A tall, thin, gray Waffen SS officer has a request for the Rosner brothers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's drunk, morose; it seems unlikely he'll be on his feet much longer. Indeed, as Henry and Leo Rosner begin the son -- an excessively melancholy tale in which a young man commits suicide for love -- the field officer staggers over to a chair in the corner of the crowded room and slumps into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth laughs too loud, drawing a weary glance from Scherner. Schindler smiles good-naturedly. He's out, a little worse for wear perhaps, a little more subdued than usual. Taking him away from the others, taking him into his confidence -- GOETH God forbid you ever get a real taste for Jewish skirt. There's no future in it. No future. They don't have a future. And that's not just good old- fashioned Jew-hating talk. It's policy now.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I want to hear "Gloomy Sunday" again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We give you Jewish girls at five marks a day, Oskar, you should kiss us, not them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is back in front of the musicians, swaying precariously, a drink in his hand -- SS OFFICER "Gloomy Sunday" again. Again they play the song. Again he staggers across the crowded room to his chair in the corner, paying no attention to the visiting Commandant from Treblinka or anybody else -- TREBLINKA GUY -- We can process at Treblinka, if everything is working? I don't know, maybe two thousand units a day. He shrugs like it's nothing, or with modesty, it's unclear. Goeth is dully impressed; Schindler, only politely so.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now Auschwitz. Now you're talking. What I got is nothing, it's like a... a machine. Auschwitz, though, now there's a death factory. There, they know how to do it. There, they know what they're doing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: wavering before Henry and Leo. This time they don't wait for him to ask for it -- LEO ROSNER "Gloomy Sunday" As the man stumbles back to his chair, the Rosners not only play the song again, they play with it, and him, this one somber man in the corner staring at them almost gratefully, wrenching from the song all the sentimentality they can, as if they could actually drive him to kill himself. No one else in the room is aware of the exchange going on between them -- this man and this music -- which the brothers play as if it were an invocation. Eventually, though, someone does become aware, if not of the intention, at least of the repetition, and interrupts the spell -- GOETH Enough -- Jesus -- God -- The music falls apart. The brothers find Goeth in the crowd looking at them like, Come on, for Christ's sake play something else. Which they do -- defeated -- some innocuous Von Suppe. Goeth turns back to one of his guests. Glancing back, as they play, to the corner, the Rosners see the gloomy SS officer getting slowly up from his chair. He stands there for a moment, staring at nothing, then slowly makes his way out onto the balcony where he stands in the night air, absolutely still, in silhouette to the Rosners. And, ruining a perfectly good party, he takes out a gun and shoots himself in the head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .E.F. - DAY From a distance, Schindler can be seen arguing with an SS officer who's trying to hand him papers, orders of some kind, which the irate industrialist refuses to accept. Here, closer, carrying blankets and bundles, Schindler's workers are marched under heavy guard out of the factory and its annexes and across the fortified yard. His people are being taken. Where, is unclear. Schindler abruptly breaks off the discussion with the SS man, climbs into his car and drives off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY A creek flowing gently through marshy ground under an umbrella of trees. Leo John and his five year old son, on their knees catching tadpoles, seem unaware of, or at least not distracted by, a ghastly endeavor going on beyond them: Bodies being exhumed out of the earth, out of the mass graves in the forest. The dead lay everywhere, victims of the ghetto massacre, victims of Plaszow. Arriving, Schindler sees Goeth standing up at the tree line. Approaching him, furious, he hesitates. He sees a wheelbarrow trundled by Pfefferberg, a corpse in it. He fears the body is Mila's, but then sees her trundling another barrow, another corpse in it. Goeth calls to Schindler -- GOETH Can you believe this? Goeth shakes his head, dismayed. Schindler joins him and stares at a pyre of bodies built by masked and gagging workers, layer upon layer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's always something. He glances off. The pyre has reached the height of a man's shoulder. The workers move around it dousing it with gasoline.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sighs at the unfairness of it all, the dissolution of his kingdom. His glance finds his man, Leo John, over at the stream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tight on the gleeful boy with a tadpole in his hand. Behind him, smoke from the pyre rises into the sky.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm trying to live my life, they come up with this? I got to find every body buried up here? And burn it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You took my workers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indignant) They're taking mine. When I said they didn't have a future I didn't mean tomorrow. (pause) Auschwitz.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is good. I'm out of business and he's catching tadpoles with his son.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .E.F. FACTORY - NIGHT Schindler, in silhouette against the wall of glass, stares down at his deserted factory, his silent machines, the dark empty spaces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Light pouring in through the windows. White sheets over the furniture like shrouds over the dead. Schindler's personal things are gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler's Mercedes, the backseat piled high with suitcases. A border guard returns his passport to him. The barrier is lifted and he crosses into Czech countryside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A church in the main square of a sleepy hamlet. A priest and his parishioners, including Emilie Schindler, emerging from it, morning Mass over. Some guys outside a bar/cafe, hanging gout, drinking, notice the elegantly dressed gentleman outside the town's only hotel. They recognize him. They come over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler, the clothes, the car, the suitcases, the great difference between their respective stations in life. Somehow their old ne'er-do-well friend has managed to do quite well, and it amazes them. Across the square, Emilie has noticed him; and he, her. But neither makes a move toward the other. Finally she walks away; which Schindler interprets correctly to mean, Yes, check into the hotel. He tips the porter extravagantly and turns back to the guys from the bar.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, how you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me buy you a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Except for the clothes of the working class clientele, the scene is reminiscent of the SS nightclub in Cracow: Schindler, the great entertainer, working his way around the tables making sure everybody's got enough to drink, making sure everybody's happy. A guy at a table with a girl gestures him over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gestures to the bartender to refill his friend's and his date's drinks, pats the guy on the shoulder and wanders over to the next table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guy has to think; not because he doesn't know, but because his old friend Oskar is so many things it's hard to know which description to use. Finally -- BRINNLITZ GUY 2 He's a salesman.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oskar - my friend Lena.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you do? (to them both) What can I get you, what're you drinking?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing's changed. Then again, something has changed, hasn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Things worked out. I made some money over there, had some laughs, you know. It was good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now you're back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now I'm back, and you know what I'm going to do now? I'm going to have a good time. So are you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A woman asleep in the bed. The girl from the bar. In his robe, at the window, Schindler calmly smokes as he stares out at the NIGHT EXT. BRINNLITZ - DAWN The town, off in the distance, nestled against the mountains. The sun, just coming up. Closer, here, ramshackle structures, a long abandoned factory of some kind. Schindler, in leather riding gear, climbs down off a Moto- Guzzi motorcycle. He slowly wanders around, peers in through broken windows, wanders around some more. Tight on his face, torn between conflicting choices, or realizing there's no choice, or only one choice, and hating it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Goddamn it.

direction.raw_text: Schindler and Goeth on the balcony of the villa, drinking.

direction.raw_text: Goeth considers his friend, greatly puzzled. Below them lies the camp, still operating, at least for now, until the shipments can be arranged.

direction.raw_text: Goeth finds this whole line of reasoning impossible to believe. He's sure Schindler's got something else going on here he's not telling him.

direction.raw_text: Schindler admits it with a shrug.

direction.raw_text: Goeth studies him, searching for the real answer in his face. He can't find it.

direction.raw_text: Goeth thinks about it in the silence. Then a slow nod to himself. He's going to make some money out of this even if he can't figure it out. He smiles.
direction.name: direction
