direction.raw_text: one of the original D.E.F. investors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: another of the Jewish investors.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All of them. Szerwitz, his family.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: with a look that asks Schindler if he's sure about this one. He is. The keys type SZERWITZ -- TIGHT ON THE FACE of the investor who stole from Schindler, the one he threatened to have killed by the SS, and the faces of his sons -- THREE OR FOUR PAGES of names next to the typewriter. Stern, trying to count them, estimates -- STERN Four hundred, four fifty -- SCHINDLER More.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: yawning open. He takes a small valise from it and heads for Goeth's villa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: typing ROSNER -- TIGHT ON Henry Rosner, the violinist. TIGHT ON his brother, Leo, the accordionist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the other Plaszow industrialist. The same appeal Schindler made to Madritsch; the same answer, no.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DOWN another page of names.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) About six hundred -- SCHINDLER (O.S.) More.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the face of a boy, the "chicken thief." Over THE FACE OF A GIRL, the one who hid in the pit of excrement. Over the FACES we've never seen.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE SOUND OF THE KEYS OVER

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Eight hundred, give or take.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) Give or take what, Stern -- how many -- count them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: down the pages of names, trying to count them more precisely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: dealt by GOETH. They're betting diamonds, he and Schindler. A queen falls and Goeth groans his misfortune.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth's maid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: his hold card against the table, is thrown a four, sweeps it again and gets a jack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: we don't recognize is typed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: we don't recognize.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler leafing through the page of names, counting them, drinking, to the sound of the typewriter. Eventually, quietly to himself -- SCHINDLER That's it. Stern heard him and stops typing, glances over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern resumes where he left off, but then hesitates again. There's something he doesn't understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't sound right. And Schindler doesn't answer. He's avoided telling Stern the details of the deal struck with Goeth, and balks telling him now. Finally awkwardly -- SCHINDLER I'm buying them. I'm paying him. I give him money, he gives me the people. (pause) If you were still working for me I'd expect you to talk me out of it, it's costing me a fortune. Stern had no idea. And has no idea now what to say. Schindler shrugs like it's no big deal, but Stern knows it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern is really overcome by what this man is doing. What he can't figure out is why. Silence. And then -- SCHINDLER Finish the page. Stern turns back, does as he's told. Schindler drinks. Nothing but the sound of the typewriter keys. And then nothing at all. The page is done. The rest will die.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You can finish that page.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did Goeth say? You just told him how many you needed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give him the list, he'll sign it, he'll get the people ready. I have to go back to Brinnlitz, to take care of things on that end, I'll see you there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Schindler in front of a large assembly, party pin in his lapel, as usual, imposing SS guards on either side of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks out over his audience, the citizens of Brinnlitz, local government officials, many of them appearing bewildered by him or the "situation" that has arisen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His estranged wife is there. So are the guys he was drinking with.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone seems to breathe sighs of relief as if they've been waiting for him to say this, to dispel the disturbing rumors they've heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The noise begins, his audience's angry reaction. Raising pitch of his own voice -- SCHINDLER -- It is my duty to supervise them -- and it is your duty to allow me -- He barely gets it all out before the protests drown him out. The uproar reaches such a clamoring level there's no point in his continuing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is my home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was born here, my wife was born here, my mother is buried here, this is my home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you really think I'd bring a thousand Jewish criminals into my home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These are skilled munitions workers -- they are essential to the war effort --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - PLASZOW - DAY Goeth, at his writing desk, endures the bureaucratic tedium of signing memoranda, transport orders, requisitions. He comes to Schindler's list, initials each page and signs the last with no more interest than the others. He hands the whole stack of paperwork to Marcel Goldberg, Personnel Clerk, Executor of Lists, Gangster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goldberg has the signature page of the list in a typewriter. He carefully aligns it and types his own name in a space allowed by the bottom margin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At a folding table in the middle of the field, Schindler signs his name to Reich Main Office directives, Evacuation Board and Department of Economy form, Armaments contracts. Around him, the new camp is taking shape: Electric fences are going up, watchtowers, barracks; shipments of heavy equipment, huge Hilo machines, are being off-loaded from flatbed train cars; SS engineers stand around frowning at the lay of the land, some drainage problem no doubt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A train full of people destined for Auschwitz pulls away from the platform. As Goldberg gathers his paperwork, a prisoner approaches him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He knows what the prisoner means and the prisoner knows he knows. He means Schindler's List.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The prisoner knows that, too, and discreetly turns over to Goldberg a couple of diamonds from the lining of his coat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Am I on the list?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What list is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The good list? Well, that depends, doesn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Names on a notepad, the first few crossed out. Goldberg types the next name onto a page of The List, squeezing it into the upper margin, and crosses that one out on the pad. He rolls the page down, types another name, tires of the exacting task, tears the handwritten page of names from the notepad, crumples it and throws it away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler, on his way back to his hotel after a night of drinking, is jumped by three guys, wrestled to the ground and brutally kicked. As the forms of his attackers move away, he catches a glimpse of one of them -- his "friend" who admired his car when he first arrived back in town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pfefferberg, his head under the hood of a German staff car, adjusting the carburetor. Goldberg comes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pfefferberg glances up from his work and studies the blackmailing collaborator for a long moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pfefferberg suddenly attacks him with the wrench in his hand, beating him across the shoulders and head with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goldberg goes down, tries to scramble away on his knees, the blows coming down hard on his back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He makes it outside the garage and runs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Poldek, how's it going? (Pfefferberg ignores him) You know about the list? You're on it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course I'm on it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want to stay on it? What do you got for me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do I got for you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Takes diamonds to stay on this list.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll kill you, that's what I got for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, all right, all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A cattle car is coupled to another, the pin dropped into place. On the platform, clerks at folding tables shuffle paper while others mill around with clipboards, calling out names. Thousands of prisoners on the platform, some climbing onto strings of slatted cars on opposing tracks. Some already in them, most standing in lines, changing lines, the end of one virtually indistinguishable from the beginning of another. Paperwork. Lists of names. Pens in hands checking them off. Some bound for Brinnlitz, the rest for Auschwitz, if they can be properly sorted from one another. A boy is allowed to remain in a line with his father; his mother is taken to another line composed of women and girls. This segregation is the only recognizable process going on; the others, if they exist, are apparent only to the clerks and guards, and maybe not even to them. It is chaos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A train snakes across the dark landscape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern, wedged into a corner of an impossibly crowded car. This train may be headed for Schindler's hometown, but it is no more comfortable than the others on their way to Auschwitz -- Birkenau.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The train idles at a crossing in the middle of nowhere. Moving across the faces peering out from between the slats, it becomes apparent there are only male prisoners aboard. Below, on a dirt road, a lone Polish boy stands watching. Just before an empty train roars past from the other direction obscuring him, his hand comes up and across his neck making the gesture of a throat being slit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The train pulls into the small quiet Brinnlitz station. The doors are opened and the prisoners begin climbing down. At the far end of the platform, flanked by several SS guards, stands Schindler. To his customary elegant attire he has added a careless accouterment, a Tyrolean hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leading a procession of nine hundred male Jewish "criminals" through the center of town, Schindler ignores the angry taunts and denouncements and the occasional rock hurled by the good citizens of Brinnlitz lining the streets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Under the towering Hilo machines, a meal of soup and bread awaits the workers. As they're sitting down to it, Schindler addresses them -- SCHINDLER You'll be interested to know I received a cable this morning from the Personnel Office, Plaszow. The women have left. They should be arriving here sometime tomorrow. He sees Stern among the workers, smiles almost imperceptibly, turns and walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A train backs slowly along the tracks toward an arched gatehouse. The women inside the cattle cars don't need a sign to tell them where they are, they've seen this place in nightmares. Pillars of dark smoke rise from the stacks into the sky. It's Auschwitz.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The stunned women climb down from the railcars onto an immense concourse bisecting the already infamous camp. As they're marched across the muddy yard by guards carrying truncheons, Mila Pfefferberg stares at the place. It' so big, like a city, only one in which the inhabitants reside strictly temporarily. To Mila, under her breath -- WOMAN Where are the clerks? So often terrified by the sight of a clerk with a clipboard, it is the absence of clerks which unsettles the woman now, as though there remains no further reason to record their names. Mila's eyes return to the constant smoke rising beyond the birch trees at the settlement's western end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler comes out of his office and, passing Stern's desk, mumbles -- SCHINDLER They're in Auschwitz. Before Stern can react, Schindler is out the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MOMENTS LATER - DAY As he strides across the factory courtyard toward his motorcycle, Schindler is intercepted by some Gestapo men who have just emerged from their car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The looks on their faces tell him he's not going anywhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These guys are serious.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your friend Amon Goeth has been arrested.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause) I'm sorry to hear that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are some things that are unclear. We need to talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd love to, it'll have to wait until I get back. I have to leave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, okay, let's talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In Breslau.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Breslau? I can't go to Breslau. Not now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A young silver-haired doctor moves slowly along rows of Schindler's women, considering each with a pleasant smile even as he makes his selections, with tiny gestures, for the death chambers. He pauses in front of one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She could lie, and he'd have killed her for it. She could tell the truth, and he'd have her killed for that, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doctor nods pensively, understandingly, it seems. Then -- YOUNG DOCTOR And who on earth is Oskar Schindler? He glances around hopelessly. One of the SS guards who accompanied the women from Plaszow speaks up -- PLASZOW GUARD He had a factory in Cracow. Enamelware. The doctor nods again as if the information were valuable, as if it meant something to him. It doesn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles to himself and gets on with the "examination," this woman to this line, this other one to that.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How old are you, Mother?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause) Sir, a mistake's been made. We're not supposed to be here, we work for Oskar Schindler. We're Schindler Jews.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A potmaker?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In a dank cell, in uniform, Amon Goeth waits. Schindler is on his way, hopefully. Maybe he's already here. Schindler will vouch for him. Schindler will straighten this out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a large room, Schindler sits before a panel of twelve sober Bureau V investigators and a judge of the SS court.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Everything you say will be held in confidence. You are not under investigation. You are not under investigation. Mr. Goeth is. He is being held on charges of embezzlement and racketeering. You're here at his request to corroborate his denials. Our information onto his financial speculations comes from many sources. On his behalf there is only you. We know you are close friends. We know this is hard for you. But we must ask you -- SCHINDLER He stole our country blind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In Schindler's absence, the workers attempt to operate the unfamiliar machines, to figure out the unfamiliar process of manufacturing artillery shells. There's movement, there's noise, the machines are running, but little is being produced. Untersturmfuhrer Jose Liepold, the Commandant of Schindler's new subcamp, moves through the factory conducting an impromptu inspection. He points out to a guard a kid no more nine, sorting casings at a work table, and another boy, ten or eleven, carrying a box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mila and another woman cross back toward their barracks carrying a large heavy pot of broth. Not more than a hundred meters away stand the birch trees and crematoria, the smoke pluming even now, at NIGHT out of the darkness appear "apparitions," skeletal figures which surround the two women, or rather the soup pot between them, dipping little metal cups into it, over and over. Too startled to speak, Mila can only stare. The apparitions clamor around the pot a moment more, than furtively slip back into the same darkness from which they came. Mila and the other woman exchange a glance. The pot is empty.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where's Schindler now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In his en, over cognac, Auschwitz Commandant Rudolf Hoss considers the documents Schindler has brought: the list, the travel papers, the Evacuation Board authorization. Hoss nods at them, then at Schindler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler seems to think about the offer as he nurses his drink. It's "tempting."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ones on the list in Hoss' hand. Silence. Then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, because you get to know them? Because you begin to see them as human beings? Schindler suddenly has the awful feeling that the women are already dead. Hoss misinterprets the look.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're right, a clerical error has bee made. (pause) Let me offer you this in apology for the inconvenience. I have a shipment coming in tomorrow, I'll cut you three hundred from it. New ones. These are fresh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The train comes, we turn it around, it's yours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I appreciate it. I want these.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You shouldn't get stuck on names.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right, it creates a lot of paperwork.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A large assembly of women. Guards calling out names from a list. As each woman steps out of line, a guard unceremoniously brushes a swathe of red paint across her clothes. New columns are formed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler, standing at the end of the platform stone-faced, watches the women whose names he is "stuck on," whose clothes are slashed with red paint, climbing onto the cattle cars. As the cars fill, a train on another track arrives. The "fresh" ones Schindler turned down. As the gates are closed on the women's cars, the gates of the others are opened and the people spill out. A horrified cry suddenly breaks through the noise of the engines. One of Schindler's women, locked in, has seen her son among those coming down off the train on the opposing track. Another cry erupts, and another, another, as the women spot their children, confiscated from the Brinnlitz factory, brought here. Schindler becomes aware of what's happening and, passing over other children, tries to corral these particular boys, many of whom have noticed their mothers now and are echoing their tortured cries with their own. Schindler manages to gather them together, the fifteen or twenty boys, and, in the middle of the crowded platform, appears to a guard:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He points across to the women's train, then down to the boys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guard glances from the frantic gentleman to the anxious brook around him. These are essential workers?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler is nodding his head, trying to think. The women are shrieking their sons' names. The guard, who heard it all, every excuse imaginable, is just turning away when Schindler thrusts his smallest finger at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guard stares at him dumbly. This he hasn't heard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: These are mine. They're on the list. These are my workers. They should be on the train.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're skilled munition workers. They're essential.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're boys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Their fingers. They polish the insides of shell casings. How else do you expect me to polish the inside of a 45 millimeter shell casing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Like a mirage in the distance they appear -- the women, the children, guards, Schindler, marching across a field toward the factory. At the perimeter of the camp, at the wire, the men watch the approaching procession. It appears to them that the women are covered in blood -- or -- could it be paint? They're walking, they're fine, some are even smiling. Liepold isn't smiling. Neither is Schindler; at least not on the outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The machines are silent, the people are not. Women are in their husbands' arms, sons in their fathers'. There's food on the tables but it's largely ignored, the reunion taking precedence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SAME TIME - DAY Schindler stands before the assembled camp guards. They are seated at the long tables, their food getting cold, waiting for him to say whatever it is he has to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes meet Liepold's, hold his icy stare, then return to the guards, most of whom look like tired middle-aged reservists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he steps away he gestures to some kitchen workers. They tear open cases of schnapps and begin setting the bottles out on the tables.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Under Department W provisions, it is unlawful to kill a worker without just cause. Under the Businesses Compensation Fund I am entitled to file damage claims for such deaths. If you shoot without thinking, you go to prison and I get paid, that's how it works. So there will be no summary executions here. There will be no interference of any kind with production. In hopes of ensuring that, guards will no longer be allowed on the factory floor without my authorization.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For your cooperation, you have my gratitude.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Schindler strolls through his factory looking over the shoulders of the workers, nodding his approval. The place is in full operation, finally; the people, having figured out the complicated Hilos, turning out shells by the caseload. Schindler pauses at one of the machines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler nods. Then frowns. He leans down and taps at the crystal of one of the gauges.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The worker kneels down, takes a look. It looks right to him. Reaching over, Schindler changes the calibration of the machine with a cavalier adjustment to a knob -- and all the gauge readings shift.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wanders off. The worker stares after him. He's just screwed up settings that took weeks to get right. Schindler comes up to another worker, Levartov, the hingemaker. He's at a machine buffing shells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler nods, watches him work, eventually glances away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Levartov, following Schindler's gaze, nods uncertainly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Levartov just stares. It's been years since he's been allowed, indeed inclined, to perform Sabbath rites.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler heads off. The rabbi keeps staring. Schindler gestures back to him, offering casually -- SCHINDLER Come on. Levartov looks around. Finally, he hangs up his goggles and follows after Schindler.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How's it going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. It's taken a while to calibrate the machines, but it's going good now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This isn't right, is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There. That looks right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's it going, Rabbi?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sun's going down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is Friday, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should be preparing for the Sabbath, shouldn't you? What are you doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got some wine in my office. Why don't we go over there, I'll give it to you. Come on, let's go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Under the shadow of a watchtower, among the roof-high tiers of bunks strung with laundry, Levartov recites Kiddush over a cup of wine to workers gathered around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On their bunks, the guards relax with schnapps, cards and magazines. One of them becomes distracted by a distant sound. Some of the others begin to hear it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Conversations cease. The barracks gradually becomes quiet, silent, all the guards straining to hear. It sounds like... singing. It sounds like Yiddish singing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: SAME TIME - NIGHT On a watchtower, a night sentry, unsure where it's coming from, listens to the distant singing. It seems like it's emanating from the surrounding hills, from the trees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SAME TIME - NIGHT At his small desk, Liepold is typing a letter, denouncing Schindler most likely. The pounding keys bury all other sounds but when he pauses to reread what he's typed, he hears it, the singing, faint, far away. He goes to his window, peers out, listens for a moment more, then hears nothing. Only the night creatures.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door to an apartment opens from the inside revealing Emilie Schindler. She coolly considers the visitor on her doorstep, her estranged husband, looking great as usual, bottle of wine in his hand, smiling as if nothing is wrong between them, as if nothing is wrong in the entire world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two of them at the kitchen table in a modest apartment, drinking, at least he is. He's trying to ask her something, but he's not sure how to put it, he wants to get it right. Finally the words just tumble out -- SCHINDLER I want you to come work for me. There, he's said it. But the bewildered look on Emilie's face wonders, That's what was hard for you to say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's the only woman he's even known who could make him nervous just sitting across a table from him, saying nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His voice trails off. A shrug adds, What do you think? She doesn't answer, but she does love him. He loves her, too. It really is a shame they're not right for each other and never will be.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You don't have to live with me, I wouldn't ask that. (pause) It's a nice place. You'd like it. It looks awful. You get used to that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right -- (now he'll be honest) We can spend time together that way. We can see each other, see how it goes -- without the strain of -- whatever you want to call it when a man, a husband and a wife go out to dinner, go have a drink, go to a party, you know. This way we'll see each other at work, there we are, same place, we see how it goes...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Stern glances up from his work; Schindler and Emilie have come in and are walking toward the accountant's desk. He gets up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like the doormen and waiters of Cracow, Stern too never imagined Schindler was married and has trouble hiding his astonishment now. He extends his hand to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It sounds strange to Stern hearing Schindler actually say it. He's never said it before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not sure what she's going to do there, she's not a nurse or a doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler nods, looks around, shrugs, offers his arm to his wife, perhaps to take her on a tour of the place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Schindlers leave. Stern sits back down at his desk and smiles. He's never seen Schindler so uncomfortable.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Itzhak Stern, Emilie Schindler. My wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stern is my accountant and friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Emilie's offered to work in the clinic. To... work there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to her) That's very generous of you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was a pleasure meeting you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pleasure meeting you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Schindler comes in carrying a radio. He sets it down on a bench where Pfefferberg's working on the frame of a machine motor with a blow torch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leaves. Pfefferberg plugs it into an outlet and switches it on. It works perfectly. A waltz.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Can you fix it? The radio.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong with it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How should I know? It's broken. See what you can do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In a male barracks, a group of workers including Pfefferberg huddle in a corner around the radio, straining to hear through heavy static a broadcast by the BBC, the Voice of London, a sketchy report of an Eastern offensive by Allied Russian forces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As a camp doctor attends to sufferers of dysentery, Schindler and Emilie sort pairs of prescription glasses from a parcel, shipped from Cracow. Stern comes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler sifts through the glasses still in the box, comes up with a particular pair and holds them proudly. Not quite sure what he's seeing is real -- STERN They arrived.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern allows himself a smile, a rare thing for him. Schindler carefully slips the new glasses onto the accountant's face. He looks around the clinic, Stern, eventually settling on Emilie, crystal clear, standing near a picture on the wall which, in other circumstances, he'd find less than reassuring: Jesus, his heart exposed and in flames.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We need to talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stern.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They arrived, can you believe it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATER - DAY In a quiet corner of the clinic, Schindler concentrates on the disquieting news Stern has brought him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler nods soberly. Then dismisses the problem with a shrug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Stern is worried about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern slowly shakes his head 'no.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler eventually nods, in agreement it seems.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern's not sure he sees the logic. Whether the shells are manufactured here or elsewhere, they'll still eventually reach their intended destination, into the hearts and heads of Germany's enemies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's another difference. The main one. The only one Schindler cares about. Silence. Then:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We've received a complaint from the Armaments Board. A very angry complaint. The artillery shells, the tank shells, rocket casings -- apparently all of them -- have failed quality-control tests.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that's to be expected. They have to understand. These are start- up problems. This isn't pots and pans, this is a precise business. I'll write them a letter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're withholding payment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, sure. So would I. So would you. I wouldn't worry about it. We'll get it right one of these days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a rumor you've been going around miscalibrating the machines. (Schindler doesn't deny it) I don't think that's a good idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause) No?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They could close us down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. Call around, find out where we can buy shells and buy them. We'll pass them off as ours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know what you're saying, but I don't see the difference.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't? I do. I see a difference.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll lose money. That's one difference.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fewer shells will be made.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stern, if this factory ever produces a shell that can actually be fired... I'll be very unhappy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A nineteen year old boy with his hands in the air stands terrified before Commandant Liepold and the revolver he wields. Workers, trying to reduce the likelihood of getting hit by a stray bullet when Liepold fires on the boy -- which seems a certainty -- scramble out of the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Liepold swings the gun around at the voice, pointing it for a moment at Schindler, who is striding toward him, then aims the barrel back at the boy's head, and yells -- LIEPOLD Department W does not forbid my presence on the factory floor. That is a lie. He waves a document at Schindler, throws it at him. Schindler doesn't bother picking it up. Instead, pointing at the boy, he yells to Liepold -- SCHINDLER Shoot him. Shoot him! Liepold is so startled by the command, he doesn't shoot. He doesn't lower the gun, though, either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His finger is on the trigger, Liepold is torn, frustrated, hating the situation he has created. As the moments without a blast stretch out, both and Schindler begin to settle down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler glances to the boy. Then at the silent Hilo beside him. Part of it is blackened from an electrical fire. To the boy, concerned -- SCHINDLER The machine's broken? The boy, too terrified to speak, nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Liepold glances to him. He seems almost distraught by the destruction of the machine, Schindler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Liepold isn't sure that's correct, but he has no documentation, at least not on him, to refute it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Hey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shoot him without a hearing. Come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He sabotaged the machine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The prisoner is under the jurisdiction of Section D. I'll preside over the hearing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But the machine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The machine is under the authorization of the Armaments Inspectorate. I will preside over the hearing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In the machine-tool section, a "judicial table" has been set up. At it sit Schindler, Liepold, two other SS officers, and an attractive German girl, a stenographer. The "saboteur," the boy, Janek, stands before the court.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Commandant Liepold was watching me trying to figure it out. I switched it on and it blew up. I didn't do anything. All I did was turn it on. Gone tonight is Schindler's usual shop-floor familiarity. He studies the boy solemn-faced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler dismisses the defensive comment with a wave of his hand and gets up. He comes around and paces slowly before the boy. Eventually, Janek dares to speak again -- JANEK Sir? Schindler glances up at him distractedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler stops, looks to the panel, and back to the boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler slams the back of his hand so hard across Janek's face, the boy almost falls. He's stunned. So are the others at the table. They've never seen such violence from the Direktor. He roars -- SCHINDLER The stupidity of these people. I wish they were capable of sabotaging a machine. Schindler's hand comes up again and Janek recoils, expecting another blow. Schindler manages to hold it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A guard escorts the prisoner away. The panel members glance among themselves. Is that it? Schindler faces them and groans in dismay.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm unfamiliar with the Hilo machines. I don't know why I was assigned there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're not skilled at armaments work, you shouldn't be here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a lathe operator.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did adjust the pressure controls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know that much about them. Somebody had set the pressure controls wrong. I had to adjust --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get him out of my sight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Liepold at his desk, typing again. This time there is no doubt he is composing a letter denouncing Schindler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler and Emilie, her arm in his, stand around like unwanted guests at the party. They probably are. Him anyway. The other guests include local politicians who fought and failed to keep his camp out of Brinnlitz. Whenever his glance meets one of theirs, they smile tightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not at all nice. He feels out of place, a feeling he's not accustomed to. Fortunately, a man in uniform, someone Schindler can relate to, approaches cheerfully, his hand outstretched.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man lives well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods. Schindler goes off in search of the bartender. Rasch watches after him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Emilie) Isn't this nice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oskar, good of you to come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you kidding, I never miss a party. Police Chief Rasch, my wife Emilie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have a lovely home. It is nice. Big.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, God, you don't have a drink?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Emilie) Wine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your husband's a very generous man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wry) He's always been.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATER - NIGHT Rasch and Schindler sharing cognac in the privacy of the Police Chief's study. Beyond the closed doors, the party continues, the sounds filtering in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rasch calmly nurses his drink, his eyes revealing nothing of what's going on behind them, except that the statement requires some elaboration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rasch smiles faintly. Yes, he's familiar, as are officials throughout much of Europe, with the gratitude of Oskar Schindler.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I need guns.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One of these days the Russians are going to show up unannounced at my gate. I'd like the chance to defend myself. I'd like my wife to have that chance. My civilian engineers. My secretary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause; then, philosophically) We're losing the war, aren't we.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It kind of looks that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blithely) Pistols?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pistols, rifles, carbines ... (long pause) I'd be grateful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Poldek Pfefferberg holds up a pistol, feels its weight, points it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pfefferberg smiles, lowers the gun, kneels beside an open crate of weapons: a couple of revolvers and rifles, an old carbine.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (calmly) Careful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: From high above the factory, Stern can be seen among the machines talking with a worker. The man points up and returns to his work. Stern stares up, puzzled. He locates a ladder that connects the shop-floor to a series of overhead planks and, with trepidation, climbs. He reaches a shaky landing high above the machines, navigates the primitive catwalks with great care, comes to a large water tank near the workshop ceiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Above the rim of the tank, amid rising steam, Schindler's head appears. Then disappears. Stern climbs a set of rungs on the tank, reaches the top and finds inside, lolling in the steaming water, Schindler and the blonde stenographer from the trial.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neither Schindler nor the blonde seems the least bit embarrassed. Only Stern. He tries hard to pretend the girl isn't there, but he just can't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler floats over closer to him, waits for him to report whatever it is he has come to report, leans closer. Finally, quietly -- STERN Do you have any money I don't know about? Hidden away someplace? Schindler thinks long and hard...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence except for the gently lapping water. Half-joking -- SCHINDLER Why, am I broke? Stern glances away, doesn't answer, just stares off. And a slight, slight smile, a gambler's philosophical smile upon being purged of his wealth, appears on Schindler's face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stern.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll talk to you later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, what, what is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In the distance, a lone boxcar, stark against the winter landscape. There are patches of snow on the ground. A cold wind blows through bare trees.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Poldek.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Tight on Poldek Pfefferberg's eyes behind a welder's mask. He turns from his work to the voice, welding torch in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The torch firing at ice as hard as metal, blue flame, white steam. Pfefferberg's eyes behind the mask again, concentrating. Around the abandoned boxcar, in the gruesome cold, stand Schindler, Emilie, a doctor, some workers and some SS guards, watching, waiting. Pfefferberg steps back. Sledge hammers pound at locks. Hands pull at levers. The doors begin to slide. Out of darkness, from inside the boxcar as the doors slide open, Schindler's face is revealed, tight. He stares for an interminable moment before walking slowly away. Inside the boxcar is a tangle of limbs, a pyramid of corpses, frozen white. From a distance, a tableau: the boxcar, the workers and guards and Emilie outside it, Schindler, off to himself several steps away, all of them still as statues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beyond a country church, among the stone markers of a small cemetery, walk Schindler and a priest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The priest nods; he seems relatively empathic. He offers an alternative -- PRIEST There's an area beyond the church reserved for the burial of suicides. Maybe I can convince the parish council to allow them to be buried there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The priest knows that. But he also knows that the provisions of Canon Law regarding who can and cannot be buried in consecrated ground are narrow.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's been suggested I cremate them in my furnaces. As a Catholic I will not. As a human being I will not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These aren't suicides.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These are victims of a great murder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In a corner of the factory, workers hammer at pine lumber. They are building coffins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As workers harness horses to carts, others hoist the coffins into them. Schindler is there, watching. He glances up at one of the guard towers, expecting, perhaps, to be felled by a bullet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beyond the wire, Rabbi Levartov leads the horse-drawn carts. Around him walk a minyan -- a quorum of ten males necessary for the rite. A few guards lag behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SAME TIME - DAY Work continues, but it's apparent in their eyes they are only physically here; in spirit they are all walking alongside the carts, one great moral force. The roar of a machine suddenly, inexplicably, dies. Then another. And another. Schindler, standing at the main power panel, pulls the last of the switches, and the factory plunges into absolute silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just beyond the perimeter of the Catholic cemetery, the minyan quickly and quietly recites Kaddish over the dead as their coffins are lowered into individual graves. Then, there is only a low breathing of wind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amon Goeth, in civilian clothes, emerges from a car. His eyes, sallow from inadequate sleep, sweep across the fortified compound with envy. It's a nice place Oskar's got here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SAME TIME - DAY Stern, at a window, stares down at Goeth beside his car. Softly, gravely -- STERN What's he doing here? Schindler appears beside Stern, glances down. He's lost weight, Goeth. The old suit he wears seems too big for him. Alone down there he seems disoriented.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Probably looking for a handout.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Workers glance up at a horrible apparition from the pit of their foulest dreams -- Amon Goeth crossing through the factory. Schindler, his arm around the killer's shoulder as if he were a long lost brother, leads him across the shop-floor, proudly pointing out to him the huge thundering Hilo machines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler takes an old suitcase from his office closet, sets it on his desk, snaps it open revealing clothes, Goeth's uniforms, his medals. The ex-Oberstrumfuhrer touches the fabric gently, then glances up gratefully to his friend.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Beyond the frosted glass of Schindler's office door, Stern can see the wavering forms of the two Nazi Party members sharing cognac and stories.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Warmed by cognac and friendship, Goeth comes through the factory again carrying the suitcase, Schindler at his side, steering him to some degree. Goeth's hand comes up to his cheek as if to brush away a bothersome fly. But it isn't a fly. One of the workers has spit on him. He turns in disbelief. Silence as his hand drops to his side, to the holster he forgets isn't there. He glances around for SS guards... who aren't there. He looks to Schindler, thoroughly confused, and whispers -- GOETH Where are the guards?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goeth stares at him bewildered. Then again at the worker who spit. Then at other workers, the resolve in their eyes. They know he has no power here, and sense he has no power anywhere. His own eyes drift to a woman with yarn in her lap, knitting needles in her hands. Is this a dream?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler good-naturedly throws an arm around Goeth's shoulder and leads him away. The workers watch as the two Germans disappear out the factory doors.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The guards aren't allowed on the factory floor. They make my workers nervous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll discipline him later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A guard slowly turns the dial of a radio, finding and losing in static several different voices in several languages, none of them lasting more than a moment. Depression hangs over the barracks. Most of the guards are straining to hear the news they've been fearing for some time now, some on their bunks just staring, one at a window peering out at the black face of a forest as if expecting, at any moment, to see Russian or American troops appear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SAME TIME - EVENING Another radio. Workers, like the guards, straining to hear. The dial finds, faint, mired in static, the idiosyncratic voice of Winston Churchill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SAME TIME - EVENING Schindler on Liepold's doorstep. The two men considering each other across the threshold. Radio static filters out from Liepold's room. The word "Eisenhower" cuts through before the speaker's voice is buried again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and walks away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's time the guards came into the factory.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: All twelve hundred workers and all the guards are gathered for the first time on the factory floor. Tension and uncertainty surround them. It's ominously quiet. Then -- SCHINDLER The unconditional surrender of Germany has just been announced. At midnight tonight the war is over. It is not his intention to elicit celebration. Indeed, his words, echoing and fading in the factory, echo the doubts they all feel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not by Untersturmfuhrer Liepold. He stands with his men, dying to lift his rifle and fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's looking at the guards, thanking them, which thoroughly confuses the workers. Just when they thought they knew where his sentiments lay, he's thanking guards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or is he attempting to adjust reality, to destroy the SS as combatants, to alter the self-image of both the guards and the prisoners? Moving across the SS men's faces, they remain inscrutable. Schindler turns his attention back to the workers, and, not at all like a confession, but rather like simple statements of fact:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That worries the workers. Whenever he leaves, something terrible always seems to happen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the quiet, in the silence, drifting slowly across the faces of the workers -- the elderly, the lame, teenagers, wives beside husbands, children beside their parents, families together -- it becomes clear, if it wasn't before, that both as a prison and a manufacturing enterprise, the Brinnlitz camp has been one long sustained confidence game. Schindler has never stood still so long in his life. He does now, though, framed by his giant Hilo machines, silent at the close of the noisiest of wars, his head bowed, mourning the many dead. When he finally does look up he sees that he is the last to do so. The faces, few of which he recognizes, are all looking at him. He turns to speak to the guards along the wall again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Apprehension spreads across the factory like a wave. Pfefferberg tightens his grip on the pistol under his coat. His ragtag irregulars do the same, the rest of their ersatz "arsenal" concealed behind a machine. To the guards:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guards hold their weapons, as they have from the moment they arrived here tonight, at attention, waiting it seems, to be given the official order from their Commander, Liepold, who appears ready to give it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long, long silence. Finally, one of the guards slowly lowers his rifle, breaks ranks and walks away. Then another. And another. And another. Another. When the last is gone, the workers consider Liepold. He appears more an oddity than a threat. He is more an oddity than a threat. And he knows it. He turns and leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tomorrow, you'll begin the process of looking for survivors of your families. In many cases you won't find them. After six long years of murder, victims are being mourned throughout the world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've survived. Some of you have come up to me and thanked me. Thank yourselves. Thank your fearless Stern, and others among you, who, worrying about you, have faced death every moment. (glancing away) Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've shown extraordinary discipline. You've behaved humanely here. You should be proud.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a member of the Nazi party. I'm a munitions manufacturer. I'm a profiteer of slave labor, I'm a criminal. At midnight, you will be free and I will be hunted. (pause) I'll remain with you until five minutes after midnight After which time, and I hope you'll forgive me, I have to flee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In memory of the countless victims among your people, I ask us to observe three minutes of silence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know you've received orders from our Commandant -- which he has received from his superiors -- to dispose of the population of this camp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now would be the time to do it. They're all here. This is your opportunity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or... (he shrugs) ...you could leave. And return to your families as men instead of murderers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A watchtower. Abandoned. The perimeter wire. No sentries. The guard barracks. Deserted. The SS is long gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler and Emilie emerge from his quarters, each carrying a small suitcase. In the dark, some distance away from his Mercedes, stand all twelve hundred workers. As Schindler and his wife cross the courtyard to the car, Stern and Levartov approach. The rabbi hands him some papers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler sees a list of signatures beginning below the typewritten text and continuing for several pages. He pockets it, this new list of names.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern steps forward and places a ring in Schindler's hand. It's a gold band, like a wedding ring. Schindler notices an inscription inside it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler slips the ring onto a finger, admires it a moment, nods his thanks, then seems to withdraw.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stern isn't sure he heard right. Schindler steps away from him, from his wife, from the car, from the workers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schindler starts to lose it, the tears coming. Stern, too. The look on Schindler's face as his eyes sweep across the faces of the workers is one of apology, begging them to forgive him for not doing more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rips the elaborate Hakenkreus, the swastika, from his lapel and holds it out to Stern pathetically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He completely breaks down, weeping convulsively, the emotion he's been holding in for years spilling out, the guilt consuming him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From above, from a watchtower, Stern can be seen down below, trying to comfort Schindler. Eventually, they separate, and Schindler and Emilie climb into the Mercedes. It slowly pulls out through the gates of the camp. And drives away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We've written a letter trying to explain things. In case you're captured. Every worker has signed it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's Hebrew. It says, 'Whoever saves one life, saves the world.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to himself) I could've got more out...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to himself) I could've got more... if I'd just... I don't know, if I'd just... I could've got more...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oskar, there are twelve hundred people who are alive because of you. Look at them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I'd made more money... I threw away so much money, you have no idea. If I'd just...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There will be generations because of what you did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't do enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You did so much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This car. Goeth would've bought this car. Why did I keep the car? Ten people, right there, ten more I could've got. (looking around) This pin --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two people. This is gold. Two more people. He would've given me two for it. At least one. He would've given me one. One more. One more person. A person, Stern. For this. One more. I could've gotten one more person I didn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They killed so many people... (Stern, weeping too, embraces him) They killed so many people...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A panzer emerges from the treeline well beyond the wire of the camp and just sits there growling like a beast. Suddenly it fires a shell at nothing in particular, at the night -- an exhibition of random spite -- then turns around and rolls back into the forest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SAME TIME - NIGHT From a watchtower, a couple of workers, having witnessed the tank's display of impotent might, can make little sense of it. Below, many of the workers mill around the yard, waiting to be liberated. No one seems to know what else to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some Czech partisans emerge from the forest. They come down the hill and casually approach the camp. Reaching the wire, they're met by Pfefferberg and some other workers, rifles slung over their shoulders. Through the fence -- PARTISAN It's all over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The partisan shrugs, Suit yourself, and wanders back toward the trees with his friends.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pause) So what are you doing? You're free to go home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When the Russians arrive. Until then we're staying here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Five headlights appear out of the night, five motorcycles marked with the SS Death's-head insignia. They turn onto the road leading to the camp gate and park, the riders shutting off the engines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shapes materialize out of the darkness within the camp. Several armed and dangerous Jews.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: LATER - NIGHT As the cyclists fill their tanks with gasoline borrowed from the camp, the workers keep their rifles pointed at them. The NCO in charge lines the gas cans neatly back up against the wire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He climbs onto his motorcycle. The others climb onto theirs. And drive away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A lone Russian officer on horseback, tattered coat, rope for reins, emerges from the forest. As he draws nearer, it becomes apparent to the workers assembling on the camp yard, that the horse is a mere pony, the Russian's feet in stirrups nearly touching the ground beneath the animal's skinny abdomen. He reaches the camp, climbs easily down from the horse and, in a loud voice, addresses the hundreds of workers standing at the fence:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is it? This one man? The workers wait for him to say more. He waits for them to move, to leave, to go home. Finally -- RUSSIAN What's wrong? A few of the workers come out from behind the fence to talk with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Russian has to think. Eventually he shrugs, 'no,' not that he saw, and climbs back onto his pony to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shrugs and gives his little horse a kick in the ribs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Russian looks confused, glances off. The quiet hamlet of Brinnlitz sits there against the mountains not half a mile away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course it is. But the idea that they could simply walk over there is completely foreign to them. The Russian rides away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You have been liberated by the Soviet Army.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you been in Poland?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just came from Poland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are there any Jews left?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where should we go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Don't go east, that's for sure, they hate you there. (pause) I wouldn't go west either if I were you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We could use some food.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't that a town over there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: All twelve hundred of them, a great moving crowd coming forward, crosses the land laying between the camp, behind them, and the town, in front of them. Tight on the FACE of one of the MEN. Tight on TYPEWRITER KEYS rapping his NAME. Tight on A PEN scratching out the words, "METAL POLISHER" on a form. Tight on the KEYS typing, "TEACHER." Tight on his FACE in the crowd. Tight on the face of a woman in the moving crowd. The keys typing her name. The pen scratching out "LATHE OPERATOR." The keys typing "PHYSICIAN." Tight on her face. Tight on a man's face. His name. Pen scratching out "ELECTRICIAN." Keys typing "MUSICIAN." His face. A woman's face. Name. Pen scratching out "MACHINIST." Keys typing "MERCHANT." Face.

direction.raw_text: A street of apartment buildings in a working class neighborhood of the city.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door to a modest apartment opens revealing Oskar Schindler. The elegant clothes are gone but the familiar smile remains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Poldek Pfefferberg out in the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Things don't look so great. Schindler isn't penniless, but he's not far from it, living alone in the one room behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pfefferberg waits out in the hall as Schindler disappears inside for a minute. The legend below appears:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, how you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. How's it going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Things are great, things are great.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm having a drink, come on in, we'll have a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean where have you been? Nobody's seen you around for a while.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puzzled) I've been here. I guess I haven't been out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought maybe you'd like to come over, have some dinner, some of the people are coming over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? Yeah, that'd be nice, let me get my coat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: GIVING THE NATIONAL SOCIALIST SALUTE, HE WAS HANGED IN CRACOW FOR CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY

direction.raw_text: . GIVING THE NATIONAL SOCIALIST SALUTE, HE WAS HANGED IN CRACOW FOR CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY. Schindler reappears wearing a coat, steps out into the hall, forgets something, turns around and goes back in.
